title: KC SIU PARTNERSHIP
full_story:
It’s now possible to earn a four-year degree in agriculture without leaving the area.
Kaskaskia College and Southern Illinois University at Carbondale have entered into a new partnership designed to expand access to affordable, high-quality agricultural bachelor’s degree options.
At the signing ceremony Tuesday at the John Cavaletto Agriculture building, Kaskaskia College President George Evans thanked SIU for joining them in thinking outside the box.
“It’s a great opportunity for our students,” Evans said.  “For individuals to come to this institution, learn from our faculty and achieve an associate’s degree in agriculture or agronomy and transfer to SIU, which is a level one research facility, one of three in the state of Illinois, and not have to leave the region.  To attend courses here and earn their transcript under the flagship of SIU, under the tutelage of SIU leaders and faculty. It’s the evolution of higher education.”
SIU Chancellor Austin Lane says this partnership demonstrates what is possible when institutions work together with a shared commitment to student success and regional growth.
“The program will be seamless,” Lane said.  “The facilities that are here at Kaskaskia are second to none.  When you think about pairing our faculty with the faculty that’s here and the amount of intellect and knowledge around agriculture, it’s going to be a game changer for our students.”
The Dean of SIU’s College of Agricultural, Life, and Physical Sciences Kristina Boone says there is a shortage to fill current openings.
“The number one issue in the agricultural industry right now is workforce and the lack of workforce,” Boone said.  “This is something that’s really important for us to be able to do, is develop our workforce in agriculture.  This innovative partnership really allows us to do that in an accessible and affordable way that also provides an excellent education.”
Evans see potential for Kaskaskia College being involved in similar programs in other fields.
“I hope we’re back here every year offering 25 different options, because in my mind… this is an absolute no brainer,” Evans said.  “We want to keep students in Illinois, we want to keep students attending our universities, going back to raise their families and staying in the region.”
The initial bachelor’s degree programs will be in Agribusiness Economics and Agricultural Systems and Education.
Under the program, some SIU professors will travel to Kaskaskia for coursework, while some will be delivered online.
Students interested in learning more or applying for one of the available agricultural bachelor’s degree pathways, may contact
.

title: EARTHQUAKE PREPAREDNESS MONTH
full_story:
It was just last month that a 3.8 magnitude earthquake shook Illinois from its center in Ohlman in central Illinois’ Montgomery County.  “Thousands of people across the state felt this last quake in the early morning hours of January 20
th
,” said Illinois Emergency Management Agency and Office of Homeland Security (IEMA-OHS) Acting Director Theodore (Ted) Berger.  “It is a cautionary reminder that we sit between two seismic zones and earthquake preparedness should be an essential part of every household’s safety plan.”
February is Earthquake Awareness Month. While hundreds of small earthquakes occur each year in the US, the worst in Illinois history occurred on December 17
th
, 1811, and was so strong that it rang a church bell in a Cairo church in southern Illinois.  It also blew smoke, sand, and coal 30 yards into the air and made the Mississippi River flow backward for a moment.
Illinois rests between the New Madrid Seismic Zone and the Wabash Valley Seismic Zone.  If you feel an earthquake or receive an alert about an earthquake, you are encouraged to “Drop, Cover, and Hold On.”  Sheltering on the floor under heavy furniture, protecting your head, and stabilizing yourself by holding onto furniture is your best chance to stay safe.  Persons using walkers or wheelchairs are advised to lock down and then cover and hold on.
IEMA-OHS also recognizes the national ShakeOut drill in October and encourages all residents to join in practicing the “Drop, Cover, and Hold On” earthquake response.
Disaster preparedness information is ready available from IEMA-OHS on the Ready Illinois website, a one-stop resource for detailed information about what to do before, during, and after disasters.

title: IECC SPIN NIGHTS
full_story:
Illinois Eastern Community Colleges (IECC) will host a series of Student/Parent Information Nights, known as SPIN Nights, next month to help prospective students and their families take the next step toward college enrollment.
Each campus will host its own SPIN Night from 5:30 to 7 pm on the following dates, at Frontier Community College on March 3
rd
, at Olney Central College on March 5
th
, at Lincoln Trail College on March 19
th
, and at Wabash Valley College at March 17
th
.
SPIN Night is designed as a one-stop opportunity for students and parents to explore IECC programs, connect with key staff members, and learn more about the enrollment process.
During the event, attendees can explore academic programs, speak with Financial Aid representatives, schedule advising appointments, learn about student clubs and organizations, and discover support services available through each campus’s Learning Commons.
“SPIN Night is about making college planning simple and approachable for both students and their families,” said Carrie Halbert, IECC Director of Student Engagement and Recruitment.  “We want them to walk in with questions and leave feeling confident about their next steps.”
Halbert said the event allows families to gather information in one setting rather than trying to piece together details on their own.
“Students can meet advisors, talk through financial aid options, and see the support systems we have in place,” Halbert said.  “It’s an opportunity to see firsthand how IECC helps students succeed from day one.”
Registration is encouraged.  Students and parents can scan the QR code included on promotional materials to select the campus and date they plan to attend.
In addition to SPIN Night activities, Lincoln Trail College will also host an Ag Exploration Night on March 19

title: CHAMP CLOSES
full_story:
First Brands Group, LLC announced Monday the permanent closure of its Champion Labs facility in Albion.
In a news release, the company said as many as 1,000 employees were notified that their employment is terminated.  Because the facility is closing in its entirety, bumping rights will not apply.
The company says it regrets the decision and described the closure as permanent.
First Brands Group stated it spent several months exploring options to avoid shutting down the Albion operation.  Those efforts included seeking additional capital and actively marketing the Champion Laboratories business in hopes of finding a buyer willing to continue operations and retain the existing workforce.  Officials said announcing a potential closure earlier could have jeopardized negotiations, as interested buyers were evaluating whether they could keep the plant running.
According to the release, a serious bidder had recently advanced in the process, with both sides exchanging draft purchase agreements.  Company leaders believed they were close to reaching a deal that would have prevented the closure.
However, the sale effort ultimately collapsed.  First Brands Group said certain facilities had been relying on outside financial support to maintain operations during negotiations.  That funding was unexpectedly withdrawn before a transaction could be completed.  The loss of that support significantly reduced the company’s valuation and eliminated any remaining viable options for a sale.
In a statement, the company said that without a completed sale, it does not have access to capital markets or sufficient cash reserves to continue operating.
First Brands Group emphasized that the decision to close was made only after exhausting all alternatives and once it became clear there was no path forward, citing the sudden withdrawal of funding and changes in the sale process as unforeseen developments that forced the expedited shutdown.

title: Churchill Downs Opens Marshall Yards Racing & Gaming in Calvert City
full_story:
Churchill Downs Opens Marshall Yards Racing & Gaming in Calvert City
Digital Content Manager
Feb 25, 2026
Feb 25, 2026
Updated
2 hrs ago
Copy article link
Churchill Downs Incorporated has announced the grand opening of Marshall Yards Racing & Gaming, a new $40 million to $45 million historical horse racing entertainment venue in southwestern Kentucky.
The 23,000-square-foot facility, located in Calvert City, will open to the public on Feb. 25, 2026. Marshall Yards becomes CDI’s eighth premier historical horse racing venue in Kentucky.
The venue features 225 state-of-the-art historical racing machines, a retail sportsbook, simulcast wagering and a variety of food and beverage offerings. Revenue generated from the new facility will support purse funding for the racing meet at Oak Grove Racing, Gaming & Hotel in Oak Grove, Kentucky.
“We are setting a new pace for growth as we expand CDI's footprint in Southwestern Kentucky,” said Bill Carstanjen, CEO of Churchill Downs Incorporated. “Marshall Yards reflects our vision to build destination experiences that generate local economic opportunities, inspire regional tourism, and secure our place at the forefront of racing and entertainment.”
Headquartered in Louisville, Churchill Downs Incorporated (Nasdaq: CHDN) has operated for more than 150 years, beginning with its flagship event, the Kentucky Derby. The company has since expanded through the acquisition, development and operation of live and historical racing entertainment venues, online wagering platforms, and regional casino gaming properties.

title: DOMESTIC DISPUTE
full_story:
On Sunday at approximately 12:20 am, Wayne County Sheriff’s Deputies were dispatched to a possible domestic violence and shots fired at a rural Cisne residence.  The victim stated they were battered by Ryan J. Musgrave after he yelled at them stating “where is my meth bag”.  The victim was able to get away from Musgrave and flee toward their vehicle as Musgrave allegedly made threats to kill them and their parents.
The victim stated, Musgrave then began firing at their vehicle with a handgun.  Deputies observed the rear window appeared to have been shot along with other holes in the rear of the vehicle that appeared to be from a firearm.  A search for Musgrave was conducted and Deputies located him pulling into his driveway at approximately 5:00 am.  Deputies attempted to stop Musgrave but he refused and fled, driving around his property until finally coming to a stop.  Deputies took Musgrave into custody without further incident.  Inside Musgraves truck Deputies recovered the suspected firearm.
Sheriff’s Deputies executed a search warrant at the residence and Illinois State Police Crime Scene technicians also collected evidence.
Ryan J. Musgrave, 40 of Cisne, faces preliminary charges of attempted murder, aggravated domestic battery, aggravated discharge of a firearm and fleeing or attempting to elude.

title: SATURDAY AFTERNOON FIRE
full_story:
The Kinmundy-Alma Fire department was called Saturday afternoon to put out a fire that spread rapidly through a large machine shed just ten feet from Fire Chief Kevin Day’s home in Kinmundy.
Day says family members were working in the basement of their home when they heard a pop and his wife walked up the stairs and yelled “fire.”  He reports the last person was in the machine shed just 20 minutes prior to the discovery, so the fire spread rapidly.  The cause of the fire is currently listed as undetermined, with a State Fire Marshal scheduled to visit the scene.  There was a space heater that was inside the building.
The machine shed is still standing, however, everything inside, including a large number of tools that Day used for his job along with his collection of Christmas displays were a total loss.  Day says there were also two vehicles inside the machine shed and two outside that were burned in the fire.  One is used in his job of selling and servicing tools for fire departments throughout the region.
Day says firemen were able to keep the fire away from his home, but some siding was melted.  Day says he plans to rebuild the machine shed; the fire call came in at around four Saturday afternoon.  Firemen were on the scene for about 2 hours.

title: IHSA HONORS DUGAN
full_story:
Flora High School Junior Gage Dugan is being honored by the IHSA.
Diagnosed with bone cancer throughout his lower legs as a child, Gage spent much of his earliest years in and out of hospitals, enduring treatment, remission, and then a second battle with cancer that lasted from ages four through eight.  Along the way, he was also diagnosed with a rare autoimmune condition that required ongoing medical care, including shots that are intended to essentially replace his immune system.
Gage caught the attention of the state this fall when he performed an incredible act of kindness for another high school student in a similar situation.  When the Wolves were slated to face Maroa-Forsyth High School in the Quarterfinal round of the IHSA Class 2A Football Playoffs in mid-November.  That week, Gage’s mom saw a Facebook post about a Maroa-Forsyth student who was battling leukemia.  Gage and his mom put together a care basket for the young man, Matthew Clary.  The basket included simple things like the game Uno, a deck of cards, coloring books, a blanket, and socks, things that Gage remembered enjoying during his own treatments.
Clary serves as the Maroa-Forsyth school mascot during games, while his older brother Michael was on the gridiron facing off against Dugan.  Flora ultimately lost the football game, but despite the outcome, Gage collected himself post-game to go present the basket, talk, encourage, and pray with Clary and his family.  As word spread of Gage’s selfless act, other schools pitched in as well.  Wilmington High School, who eventually faced Maroa-Forsyth in the state championship, collected over $1,000 for the Clary family.
Gage’s mission to give back is not limited to a single day or student.  He has fully embraced the concept through helping organize canned food drives, community events, and participating in service-based initiatives such as a “Paint a Game” fundraiser conducted in conjunction with a regular-season Flora football game this year.
Dugan’s journey is a powerful reminder that the true spirit of sport extends far beyond competition.  Through resilience, compassion, and an unwavering commitment to serving others, Gage has transformed personal adversity into a force for good, making him a truly deserving recipient of the NFHS Spirit of Sport Award.

title: OUTLAND AIRPORT SELECTED
full_story:
Mt. Vernon Outland Airport has been selected as the Terminus host site for the 2026 Air Race Classic, marking a major milestone for both the airport and Mt. Vernon.  The nationally recognized event will bring pilots, crews, aviation officials, and visitors from across the country to Mt. Vernon, making it the largest aviation event hosted at the airport since the 1973 Blue Angels air show.
The Air Race Classic is a prestigious, all-female piloted cross-country air race that traces its roots to the 1929 Women’s Air Derby.  The modern race challenges teams to fly a multi-day route across the United States, testing accuracy, flight planning, and consistency rather than pure speed.  The race concludes at the designated Terminus city, where pilots are welcomed and celebrated for their achievement.  More information about the race is available at airraceclassic.org.
“Being selected as the Terminus for the Air Race Classic is a tremendous honor for Mt. Vernon Outland Airport,” said Chris Collins, Airport Manager.  “This event puts our airport on a national stage and highlights the professionalism of our facilities and staff.  It’s exciting to host an event of this scale and significance.”
Racers and race officials are expected to begin arriving on Thursday, June 25
th
, and will remain in Mt. Vernon through Monday, June 29
th
, participating in a variety of planned events, receptions, educational opportunities, and community activities throughout their stay.
“This is truly a community-wide opportunity,” said Sheila Jolly Scrivner, Host City Terminus Chair.  “From aviation enthusiasts to families and local businesses, the Air Race Classic offers something for everyone, and we’re looking forward to showcasing Mt. Vernon’s hospitality and support for women in aviation.”
A public aviation celebration and youth activity day will be held on Saturday, June 27
th
, from 9 am to 3 pm at Mt. Vernon Outland Airport.  Activities will include Young Eagle Flights for children, interactive aviation displays, educational opportunities, and additional family-friendly programming designed to inspire the next generation of pilots and aviation professionals.
Event organizers are actively seeking local, regional, and national sponsors to support the 2026 Air Race Classic Terminus and related activities.  Sponsorship opportunities will offer businesses and organizations high-visibility exposure, community engagement, and alignment with a nationally respected aviation event that promotes education, skill, and opportunity for women pilots.
The Air Race Classic is a nonprofit organization dedicated to encouraging and educating women pilots, increasing public awareness of general aviation, and honoring the legacy of women in aviation through an annual cross-country air race.

title: SEVERE WEATHER DAMAGE
full_story:
It appears 2026 picked right up where 2025 left off in terms of severe weather.
An early-season severe weather outbreak struck Illinois Thursday.  The region along and immediately south of Interstate 70 saw the highest concentration of severe weather as preliminary reports indicated at least a couple tornadoes were observed across Effingham and Crawford counties, the National Weather Service (NWS) office in Lincoln reported.  The most severe structural damage was reported near New Hebron in Crawford County.
NWS dispatched a survey crew on Friday to assess the damage in the southeast parts of the state.  There were also numerous reports of hail damage around the state, particularly along the Illinois River Valley from the storms.
The recent outbreak follows an active year in 2025, which featured 126 tornadoes statewide, more than twice the average amount.

title: DAYLIGHT SAVINGS TIME
full_story:
Whether digital or analog, Illinoisans will set their clocks forward in just a few weeks as daylight saving time returns.
Despite years of debate in Congress about ending the twice-yearly clock change, daylight saving time remains in place for 2026.  That means most of the US, will “spring forward” on March 8
th
.
Most smartphones, computers and other connected devices will update automatically.  But people will need to manually change non-smart devices such as microwaves, older car radios and analog wall clocks.
Efforts to eliminate the biannual clock change have stalled at both the federal and state levels.
In 2022, the US Senate unanimously passed the Sunshine Protection Act, which would have made daylight saving time permanent.  The House did not take it up.  The bill resurfaced in Congress in 2025 but again failed to advance.
President Donald Trump has voiced support for ending the clock changes.  In December 2024, then-president-elect Trump said he wanted to eliminate daylight saving time and move to year-round standard time.  He reiterated that stance in April 2025.
Until Congress passes legislation and a president signs it into law, the clock changes will continue nationwide.
Clocks will move back one hour, giving most Americans an extra hour of sleep on November 1
st
.

title: YEAR ROUND E15 VOTE
full_story:
Proposed legislation supporting year-round nationwide E15 could be introduced this week with a possible full House vote the first week of March.
US Representative Darin LaHood, sits on the newly formed E15 Rural Domestic Energy Council and said last week, the group was currently writing the bill.
“This council has made good progress so far in bringing members together for a frank and open discussion, receiving feedback from stakeholders, and moving forward on the E15 bill that can pass the House and Senate and be signed into law,” LaHood told attendees of Illinois Farm Bureau’s Governmental Affairs Leadership Conference (GALC) in Springfield.
“Now this is a difficult balancing act, and the council has a diverse membership, with districts that include every side of biofuels, agriculture and, of course, the petroleum industry.  And we’re continuing to work on this legislation.  I’m confident that the council will find a reasonable solution that gives certainty to our farmers,” said LaHood, one of two Illinois congressional members on the council, including Mike Bost.
US House leadership last month opted to create a rural energy council to study biofuel issues rather than include a nationwide year-round E15 provision in a spending package, frustrating ag and biofuel groups.
One of IFB’s national legislative priorities this year is passage of year-round E15, as farmers continue to face economic challenges.  Year-round E15 would provide much needed certainty, strengthen demand for domestic fuel and create new market opportunities for growers, IFB President Philip Nelson previously said.
LaHood reiterated farmers in his district tell him they don’t want government handouts, they want markets and customers for their crops.
“One of the simplest ways we can accomplish that this year is through year-round E15,” LaHood said.  “Illinois is a leader in corn and biofuels production, and allowing for year-round E15 will help stabilize corn prices and provide additional market certainty.
“Unfortunately, states have had to rely on federal waivers to continue selling E15 in the summertime.  Congress is focused on passing legislation to support year-round E15.”

title: FMH FOUNDATION FISH TANK
full_story:
The Fairfield Memorial Hospital Foundation recently funded the installation of an aquarium on the Skilled Care Unit, made possible through memorial contributions from the family of Robert Simpson.
The idea for the aquarium began when the Simpson family reached out to the Foundation, expressing interest in supporting a special project in Robert’s memory.  After thoughtful consideration and research, the Foundation Board approved the project and partnered with Serenity Aquarium Services, a professional company that will install and maintain the aquarium on an ongoing basis.
The aquarium has been placed on the Skilled Care Unit, where residents, families, and staff can enjoy the calming and therapeutic benefits it provides.  Studies have shown that aquariums can help reduce stress and anxiety while promoting relaxation and a sense of well-being, benefits that are especially meaningful in a long-term care setting.
The Foundation Board will continue to coordinate with Serenity Aquarium Services to ensure the aquarium remains a welcoming and well-maintained feature on the Skilled Care floor.
Community members who would like to assist with the ongoing care of the aquarium are invited to donate to the Fairfield Memorial Hospital Foundation and designate their gift to “Special Project – Aquarium.”  Contributions will help support maintenance and enhancements to ensure the aquarium continues to be enjoyed for years to come.
For more information about supporting Foundation projects, please contact the Fairfield Memorial Hospital Foundation at 618-847-8356.
Front Row L-R:  Tim Sullivan, Susan Suddarth, Dana Wilson, Shelby Greenwalt (Treasurer)
Back Row L-R:  Jim Barnfield, Marty Vaughan, Hank Simmers, Chris Conard (Vice President), Matt Rush (President), Jim Basch (CFO), Andy Flemer (CEO), Chris Simpson, Lisa Simpson, Michelle Simpson, Claire Vaughan, Morgan Doggett, and Libby Lingafelter.

title: SHINEDOWN AT ISF
full_story:
The Illinois State Fair announced that multi-platinum rock powerhouse Shinedown will take the Illinois Lottery Grandstand Stage on Sunday, August 23
rd
, delivering an unforgettable night of chart-topping hits and electrifying live energy.
With a career defined by record-breaking success and creative impact, Shinedown has firmly cemented its place in music history.  The band boasts over 8.3 billion global streams, 24 No. 1 rock hits, 15 platinum and gold singles, and platinum or gold certification for every album in their catalog with songs like “Second Change,” “Simple Man” and “Sound of Madness.”  With more than 10 million albums sold worldwide, Shinedown continues to set the standard for modern rock.
The band’s latest juggernaut track, “A Symptom Of Being Human”, from their seventh studio album Planet Zero, has amassed nearly 125 million global streams and charted across five radio formats, including No. 1 at Active Rock and Top 10 placements at Alternative and Adult Contemporary.  Shinedown became the first artist in history to land a single song in the Top 10 at Active, Alternative, and Hot AC radio on Mediabase, an achievement driven by the song’s unifying message about the importance of human connection.
“Bringing an act of Shinedown’s caliber to the Illinois State Fair underscores our commitment to offering fans world-class entertainment,” said Illinois State Fair Manager Rebecca Clark.  “They are known for their explosive live shows, and this performance is sure to be a highlight of the 2026 Fair.”
Tickets for Shinedown are now on sale via Ticketmaster.  Tier 3 tickets are $60, Tier 2 tickets are $75, Tier 1 tickets are $85, Track tickets are $90, and Blue Ribbon tickets are $140.  A $30 Pre-Show Party ticket is offered as an additional upgrade for all paid concerts.
Mark your calendars for the 2026 Illinois State Fair, August 13
th
through August 23
rd
in Springfield.
Stay up to date with all the latest news and announcements from the Illinois State Fair by connecting with us via Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

title: MT ERIE KINDERGARTEN REGISTRATION
full_story:
Kindergarten registration for the Mt. Erie School will be held on Monday, March 9
th
, from 3 to 5 pm.  This registration is for all students who will be entering kindergarten in the fall at Mt. Erie School.
In order to enroll in kindergarten, a child must be five years old by September 1
st
.  Please bring a certified copy of your child’s birth certificate, from the courthouse, and your child’s Social Security card or number.  Immunization records, eye exam, dental exam, and verification of lead screening are necessary by the first day of school.

title: OREPS COMING
full_story:
Illinois State Police (ISP) Troop 9 Commander, Lieutenant Bruce Waggoner, announced that the ISP will conduct Occupant Restraint Enforcement Patrols or OREPs in Clay, Effingham, Fayette, and White counties during March.  OREPs allow the ISP to focus on safety belt and child safety seat laws.  Illinois law requires all vehicle passengers, front and back, to be buckled up.
Safety belts are still one of the most effective safety devices in vehicles, estimated to save over 14,000 lives each year.  Nearly 50% of vehicle occupants killed in traffic crashes were not buckled up.  The objective of this program is to increase occupant restraint compliance through education, child safety seat inspections, and enforcement.
This project is funded through the Illinois Department of Transportation.

title: WORKFORCE TRAINING GRANT
full_story:
The Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity awarded more than $2 million to a southern Illinois organization for workforce training.
Man-Tra-Con Corporation was awarded $2,347,608 to run a free clean energy workforce training hub for 19 southern Illinois counties.  The funding is from the state’s Climate and Equitable Jobs Act, which is investing in the training across the state as the clean energy industry grows.
According to a news release from Man-Tra-Con Corporation, its first partner, a 16-week solar installation program based in Harrisburg is now underway.  They say they aim to train 130 southern Illinois residents in year one, with more partners at locations throughout the region to be announced soon.  According to the organization, training is free, and they provide support services to help reduce some common barriers, like transportation, childcare and more.  Participants also receive a stipend of up to $13 per hour of instruction.
They say graduates can earn an OSHA 10-hour construction safety certification, First Aid/CPR Certification and would be prepared to sit for the NABCEP PV Associate exam.
Funded through the federal Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act, the organization has helped thousands of job seekers for nearly 50 years across the region.
The program serves residents in 19 southern Illinois counties, including Wayne, Edwards, Jefferson, Jackson, Williamson, Franklin, Perry, Saline, Union, Johnson, Massac, Pope, Hardin, Gallatin, White, Hamilton, Wabash, Pulaski, and Alexander.
Those interested in learning about eligibility requirements or future training dates can visit mantracon.org/ceja or call 618-428-4460.

title: LOTTERY PRIZE IN MT. VERNON
full_story:

The lucky winner has one year from the draw date to claim their prize. The Illinois Lottery encourages the winner to sign the back of their ticket and store it in a safe place until they are ready to claim their prize.
As a reward for selling the winning ticket, the store will receive a $14,982 bonus—1% of the prize amount.
Cash Castle is a $30 progressive FastPlay game. The jackpot begins at $100,000, which is the highest starting jackpot of any Illinois Lottery FastPlay game, and grows with each ticket sold statewide until the jackpot is won.
FastPlay is a style of lottery games that are quick and easy and can be played at any time. There are no numbers to pick, no play slip to complete, no scratching, and no waiting for winning numbers. The Illinois Lottery currently offers 35 FastPlay games at various price points and play styles.

title: ROUTE 66 CENTENNIAL
full_story:
The Illinois Route 66 Centennial Commission and tourism partners from across the state are celebrating the official kickoff of the Route 66 Centennial, marking 100 years since the creation of the highway.  Also known as the “Mother Road,” Route 66 begins in Chicago and runs through the heart of Illinois, connecting communities and travelers for a century.
In recognition of the centennial, the Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity is awarding nearly $4 million in grant funding to local tourism bureaus to support development, education, preservation, and promotion efforts of Route 66 activities throughout Illinois.  These awards will help communities enhance visitor experiences, preserve historic assets, and showcase Illinois’ unique role in Route 66 history says Cory Jobe, Chair of Illinois’ Route 66 Centennial Celebration Commission.

More information on the Route 66 Centennial celebration at enjoyillinois.com.

title: NORTH CLAY SCHOOL BOARD
full_story:
The North Clay School Board met Wednesday evening.
During the public comment portion of the meeting, Jon Carroll spoke to the board regarding the district’s current cell phone policies.  He stated that because the district provides dedicated technology like Chromebooks for educational use, personal cell phones have become an unnecessary distraction that compromises student engagement.  Furthermore, Mr. Carroll highlighted the safety and privacy risks associated with mobile devices in schools, ultimately urging the district to revise its policies to better safeguard the student learning environment.
Kent Kull with Kull and Associates presented the FY25 Annual Financial Report (the district audit).  He reported that North Clay earned an overall rating of “Recognized”, which is the highest rating a school district can receive.  The Annual Financial Report is now posted on the school website.  The board also approved the district calendar for the 2026-2027 school year.
After a closed session board members accept the letter of intent of retirement of Leslee West and Cheryl McGee effective at the end of the 2027-2028 school year and the resignation of Sam Erwin as 7
th
grade boys’ basketball coach.  The board also hired Cindy Rose as full time cook for the 2025-2026 school year, and Sam Erwrin as the summer of 2026 school strength and conditioning position.  Board members also selected Jordan Robey to fill the vacancy on the Board for the seat previously held by Anthony Dawkins.

title: PLUMMER ON PRITZKER
full_story:
State Senator Jason Plummer released the following statement in response to the Governor’s proposed budget and State of the State Address.
“Let’s be honest, what Governor Pritzker delivered was campaign grandstanding, not leadership.  This was not about real solutions.  It was a recycled set of talking points and cherry-picked, inflammatory claims that do nothing to relieve the pressure on Illinois families or help the businesses trying to keep jobs here.
“More spending.  More taxes.  And Illinois families are the ones stuck paying the bill.  And despite the Governor’s claims, this budget still isn’t balanced.
“This is not new.  Year after year, the Governor has built his ever-expanding budgets on gimmicks that ultimately just rely on reaching into taxpayers’ pockets for more money to fund political priorities while our core structural issues and most vulnerable citizens are ignored and neglected.
“The Governor continues to lean on the minimum required pension payment even as the system remains in serious trouble, all while shortchanging services for the developmentally disabled and the infrastructure that supports downstate communities.
“State spending has grown by nearly 40 percent since Governor Pritzker took office, and working families are paying the price.  His far left “progressive” policies are making Illinois unaffordable, from real estate taxes to utility bills to a tank of gas.  People are leaving this state.  Businesses are looking elsewhere.  Once again, Governor Pritzker has shown with this budget and his comments that he is focused on his own political opportunities, not creating lasting opportunities for Illinois families.”

title: IFB ACTION ALERT
full_story:
Illinois Farm Bureau launched an action request Wednesday calling on members to contact Illinois’ congressional delegation to support the proposed farm bill that will be marked up by the House Ag Committee starting Monday.
House Ag Committee Chair Glenn “GT” Thompson, released the Farm, Food and National Security Act of 2026 on February 13
th
.  The 2018 farm bill expired in 2023, and Congress has since extended the legislation three times.
The proposed bill is similar to farm bill legislation proposed and passed by the House Ag Committee in 2024, with a few key updates.  The proposal strengthens standing disaster programs and creates a framework to better support specialty crops, fixes Proposition 12, improves conservation programs through 2031, increases funding for trade promotion programs, updates loan limits and expands resources for new, young, beginning and veteran farmers.
Illinois Farm Bureau is calling on House Agriculture Committee members, which include US Representatives Mike Bost; Nikki Budzinski; Jonathan Jackson; Mary Miller; and Eric Sorensen, to support the bill during the committee markup, as well as encouraging non-committee members to support the bill if presented for a full floor vote.
Members are asked to contact their congressional representative and urge them to vote “yes” on the bill.
Farmers are facing depressed commodity prices, soaring input costs, persistent inflation and farm policy that has not been updated since 2018, creating prolonged uncertainty at a time when margins are razor thin and many farms are struggling to stay afloat.
A link to the action request can be found at https://ilfb.quorum.us/campaign/155789/.  The action request will be live through the House Ag Committee vote.

title: BABY FOOD RECALL
full_story:
A California-based baby food manufacturer has recalled one of its products due to elevated levels of toxins that could cause nerve damage, fevers and more.
The company, IF Copack LLC or Initiative Foods, recalled its “Tippy Toes” Apple Pear Banana Fruit Puree on Friday, February 13
th
, due to levels of patulin.  Affected products have a “Best By” date of July 17
th
, and lot number 07174.
Exposure to the naturally occurring substance can lead to immune suppression, nerve damage, headache, fever, and nausea.  However, the company hasn’t received reports of illnesses or injuries from customers, according to an announcement on the US Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) website.
According to the recall notice, the FDA sampled the baby food using its Total Diet Study tool, which monitors levels of nutrients, and contaminants, in foods people eat across the United States.  While examining the puree, federal authorities found the elevated levels of patulin.  Consumers should discard the product or return it to the place of purchase for a refund.
The baby food was sold in retail grocery stores throughout the United States, except Alaska, the company said.  It may have also been sold in the US territories of Guam and Puerto Rico.
Patulin is a naturally occurring substance called a “mycotoxin,” or a toxin produced by molds.  Patulin is produced by molds that grow in fruits such as apples.
Mycotoxins, such as Patulin, can also grow in grains, dried beans, dried fruits, and coffee, per the FDA.  Eating foods with high levels of mycotoxins can lead to immune suppression, nerve damage, headache, fever and nausea.
No illnesses or injuries have been reported as of yet.

title: GIRL SCOUT COOKIE WEEKEND
full_story:
Girl Scouts of Southern Illinois invites cookie lovers across the area to celebrate National Girl Scout Cookie Weekend, taking place February 20–22.  National Girl Scout Cookie Weekend is an annual event where Girl Scouts nationwide promote their sales and flex their entrepreneurial spirit through the iconic Girl Scout Cookie Program.  Every purchase makes a difference in the lives of young entrepreneurs as they find their way in the world and discover endless possibilities.  Joining the iconic cookie lineup this year, Exploremores, a rocky road ice cream, inspired sandwich cookie, is another delectable treat that consumers can purchase to support Girl Scouts this season.
As always, 100% of the proceeds earned through the Girl Scout Cookie Program stay local with councils and troops as they explore more possibilities through life-changing experiences and programming offered year-round.  Cookie lovers can purchase their favorite cookies in person from Girl Scouts at any local booth or can order cookies for direct shipment to their front door, or pickup, by visiting gsofsi.org/findcookies.  Customers can also text COOKIES to 59618 to find a booth near them.
Each box purchased helps fund life-changing experiences for Girl Scouts, from summer camp adventures and educational field trips to STEM activities and impactful community service projects.  When customers celebrate National Girl Scout Cookie Weekend by purchasing their favorite cookies, they’re not just enjoying a delicious dessert, they’re opening doors for girls to discover their leadership potential, build lasting friendships, and create positive change in their communities.
While picking up some cookies for yourself, you can also purchase a box or two to donate to the Bake It Forward program.  All cookies purchased through Bake It Forward will be donated to H.E.R.O.E.S. Care, an organization supporting military personnel and their families.  The Girl Scout Cookie Program runs through March 15
th
in Southern Illinois.
Girl Scouts of Southern Illinois serves over 6,300 girls and engages nearly 3,600 adults in 40 counties in Southern Illinois.  Call 800-345-6858 or email
.

title: LOWER DUI LIMIT
full_story:
Illinois lawmakers are considering a major change to the state’s DUI laws that would make the legal limit one of the strictest in the country.
House Bill 4333 would lower the blood alcohol limit from 0.08 to 0.05.  Right now, Utah is the only state with a 0.05 standard.  Supporters of the bill point to research that shows some drivers could reach that level after just one or two drinks, arguing the change could help lower traffic deaths.
The bill has been assigned to a House committee but has not been scheduled for a hearing yet.

title: RETAILERS CHEER RULING
full_story:
The leader of the Illinois Retailers Merchants Association is cheering on a ruling from a courtroom after a federal judge upheld a first-of-its-kind law.
The law aims to protect retailers from having to pay “swipe fees” when customers pay by debit or credit card.
For Rob Karr, the Chief Executive Officer of the I-R-M-A, the ruling by a federal judge is a win for every consumer across the state.
cut 1:13 “going forward.”
However, the ruling may not last long, as the Illinois Bankers Association and the Illinois Credit Union League could file an appeal soon.
According to Karr, if the ruling is appealed, the I-R-M-A will take the case to the state’s Supreme Court.

title: FMH HIRING
full_story:
Fairfield Memorial Hospital is seeking a qualified candidate for the full-time position of Director of Plant Operations to lead and oversee facility management in support of the hospital’s mission to deliver high-quality healthcare to the community.
The Director of Plant Operations is a senior leadership role responsible for ensuring the safety, functionality, and efficiency of the hospital’s physical environment.  This position oversees all aspects of facility management, including engineering, maintenance, groundskeeping, safety, and security.  As the hospital’s Safety Officer, the Director will ensure compliance with regulatory standards and best practices while collaborating with hospital leadership to plan and execute capital projects, manage budgets, and promote continuous improvement.
The ideal candidate will have seven to ten years of supervisory experience in plant operations, maintenance, or facilities management, as well as a working knowledge of building systems, safety regulations, and preventive maintenance best practices.  A bachelor’s degree in engineering, construction management, or a related field is preferred.
This full-time position offers a competitive salary range of $75,000 to $125,000, along with a comprehensive benefits package that includes health, dental, vision and disability insurance, retirement plans, paid time off, flexible scheduling, and professional development opportunities.
Fairfield Memorial Hospital is an Equal Opportunity Employer dedicated to fostering a diverse and inclusive workplace.  Interested candidates are encouraged to apply online at www.fairfieldmemorial.org/careers/open-positions or contact Human Resources at 618-847-8270 for more information.

title: MEASLES DIAGNOSED
full_story:
The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) confirmed the state’s first measles case of 2026 in an adult from the Metro East area.  This person had recently traveled out of state.
Health officials are tracing possible exposure sites, including Good Shepherd Lutheran Church in Collinsville.  Attendees there on February 8
th
from 8:00 am to 12:15 pm might have been exposed.
Dr. Sameer Vohra from IDPH stressed the importance of vaccination, noting, “This first reported case of measles in Illinois in 2026 is a reminder to our Illinois residents that this disease can be prevented with up-to-date vaccination.”
The MMR vaccine is 97% effective with two doses.  IDPH advises those exposed and not fully vaccinated to watch for symptoms like rash and fever.  Contact your healthcare provider before visiting if symptoms appear.
Travelers should check their vaccination status if heading to outbreak areas.  Use IDPH’s vaccine locator tool to find nearby vaccination sites.  Health providers should report suspected cases to local health departments.

Among the 56 historic sites, museums and monuments featured in the passport is the Western Illinois Museum in Macomb, where Jock Headblade is with the Macomb Area Convention and Visitors Bureau—known as Unforgettable Forgottonia…..
cut 1:02 ‘…..in the world.’
Passports are free and will be available at public libraries, highway visitor centers, staffed passport sites and other locations throughout Illinois.  More info is available at il250.org.

title: MASON MAN FOUND DEAD
full_story:
The Effingham County Sheriff’s Department responded to a call at just before 7 pm Friday regarding a male individual that was found burned on his property in rural Mason.  Deputies arrived and located the individual identified as Michael Macklin, age 60 of Mason.  The Effingham County Coroner’s Office and the Illinois State Fire Marshal’s Office also responded to the scene.
The preliminary investigation revealed Macklin was cutting wood and burning brush on his property.  When his wife returned home at around 6 pm she could not locate him and called a neighbor to help find him in the wooded area behind the residence.  According to the family, Michael Macklin was recently diagnosed with cardiac issues.  It appeared he suffered a medical emergency and passed away at the scene.  The brush fire he had started caused his body to be partially burned at the scene.
An autopsy was conducted Sunday at Meyer Funeral Home in Olney with results expected in approximately three weeks.  The death remains under investigation by the Effingham County Coroner’s Office, the Effingham County Sheriff’s Department and the Illinois State Fire Marshal’s Office.

title: PENNY SHORTAGE
full_story:
At the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum in Springfield, visitors can shop for sweatshirts, pillows, jewelry and chocolates using coins bearing the face of perhaps the most-famous Illinoisian, Abraham Lincoln.  But even here, pennies are growing scarce at the cash register.
The museum gift shop, like the rest of the country, is grappling with a penny shortage after the United States Mint halted production of the coin in November, citing the rising cost of producing them.  The lack of fixed guidance from the state and federal governments about how to cope with the shortage of new pennies has left some business owners scrambling to come up with ways to address it.
Many retailers are just rounding up or down to the nearest 0- or 5-cent mark in their prices to make change.  They will accept the one-cent coins, but can’t always pay them out.
For many Illinoisans, there is a sad, end-of-an-era feeling watching the slow disappearance of the one-cent coin, which was one of the first coins made by the US Mint after its establishment in 1792.  President Lincoln’s profile has been on the “heads” side since 1909, and that change made him the first president featured on U.S. coins in honor of his 100
th
birthday.
Illinois lawmakers say the penny shortage is not an issue at the top of the agenda because of factors like the popularity of cashless payment methods and the fact that there are still billions of pennies in circulation.
Still, experts say that beyond minor adjustment costs on the retailers’ end, the penny shortage won’t pose a major issue in terms of price increases simply because its value is low.

title: AIR BAG RECALL
full_story:
Millions of vehicles with Takata air bags are being slapped with a “Do Not Drive” warning by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration following a recall.  The warning was issued for certain Acura, BMW, Chrysler, Dodge, Ford, Honda, Infiniti, Mazda, Nissan, Pontiac, and Toyota vehicles including 2007 to 2016 Jeep Wranglers, 2005 to 2015 Dodge Chargers, and 2007 to 2015 Mazda CX-Nines.
According to the NHTSA, test data on the defective Takata air bag inflators in these vehicles show a far higher risk of ruptures during air bag deployment than for other recalled Takata air bags.  Drivers can see if their car is affected by using NHTSA’s Recalls Lookup Tool, and those with impacted vehicles can take them to their local dealership for free repair.

title: FLORA WOMAN SENTENCED
full_story:
Brittani Workman-Rueger, 34, of Flora was sentenced to five years in prison after pleading guilty in Marion County Court for possession of 15 to 100 grams of a substance containing methamphetamine.
Two Class X charges pending against Workman-Rueger were dropped for methamphetamine trafficking and possession with intent to deliver methamphetamine between 100 and 400 grams.  Another possession of methamphetamine charge for having possession of 100 to 400 grams was also dropped.   All are tied to Workman-Rueger’s arrest on November 16
th
, of 2023.
Workman-Rueger will serve the time concurrently with five-year prison terms handed down earlier in Clay and Effingham Counties.  When getting out of prison, Workman-Rueger will have to complete one year of mandatory supervised release.  She was given credit for 78 days already served in prison.

title: DEPUTIES HONORED
full_story:
Two Wayne County Sheriff’s Department deputies were honored by the Illinois Sheriff’s Association for saving the life of a detainee who tried to harm himself.  The officers honored are Kenny Drake and Donovan Lee.
The two officers were honored for their actions last October when they discovered an inmate had wrapped a telephone cord around his neck in an attempt to commit suicide.  The two officers rushed to the aid of unconscious inmate and called for help from Deputy Cody Moore.  After the detainee was stabilized at the jail, he was transported to Fairfield Memorial Hospital where he was treated and later released back to the county jail.
The correctional officers were also commended for making sure the inmate received mental health treatment after the incident as well as follow up care after his release from custody.

title: OIL PRODUCTION 2025
full_story:
Illinois crude oil production totaled 6,774,035 barrels in 2025, according to data compiled by the Illinois Petroleum Resources Board.  That is a slight decrease from 2024.  Clay County ranks 7
th
out of 43 counties that produce oil in the state.
In Clay County 244,337 barrels of crude oil were produced in 2025, that’s down over 25,971 barrels from 2024.  White County continues to lead the state in oil production with 2,100,336 barrels, 100,822 barrels less than 2024.
The biggest increase in oil production was in Sangamon County with a 135,000 barrel increase.  The biggest decrease in production was in White County with 101,000 less barrels in 2025.
In our area Marion County ranks 2
nd
for oil production with 676,772 barrels, Fayette County is 5
th
with 293,821, and Wayne County is 8
th
with 231,247.  Richland County ranked 13
th
, Jasper County ranked 14
th
and Effingham County ranked 21
st
.
Overall production in the state was down 6.08% from 2024 levels, down 438,162 barrels.

title: IHSA APPROVES FOOTBALL CHANGE
full_story:
The Illinois High School Association (IHSA) announced on Friday that member schools voted to approve a special by-law proposal impacting the start date of the 2026 football season and the number of practices required per player to compete in the first contest.
The proposal passed by a margin of 290 in favor, 245 opposed, and 67 with no opinion.  Voting opened on January 29
th
and seventy-five percent of the IHSA membership cast a ballot in the special election.
As a result of the vote, the first practice date of the 2026 IHSA football season will move forward to Wednesday, August 5
th
.  In addition, each player will be required to complete 12 days of on-field practices, excluding Sundays, before they are eligible to compete in their first contest.
IHSA member schools voted in December to expand the IHSA Football Playoffs by one week, and as a result, it reduced the required number of practices prior to the first contest to nine practices.  Following that vote, the IHSA conducted extensive discussions with the IHSA Sports Medicine Advisory Committee and other state and national leaders on player safety, which ultimately led the IHSA Board of Directors to initiate the process of a special vote to address both.
Craig Anderson Executive Director of the IHSA said, “Despite the cumbersome nature of the process, I am confident this outcome is in the best interest of student-athlete safety.”

title: IFB AG SUMMITS
full_story:
COUNTRY Financial and the Illinois Farm Bureau will provide essential economic and financial information for farmers at a series of ag summits throughout Illinois this month.
The events will feature presentations from the following experts, David Widmar, agricultural economist and researcher, Kris Kline, manager, financial specialists at COUNTRY Financial, and Amy Rademaker, rural health and farm safety specialist.
IFB members who attend any of the summits will receive a Peace of Mind planner, a booklet that consolidates important documents and information in one place.
“Illinois farm families are facing rising costs, financial pressures and ongoing stress that can make it difficult to step back and plan for the future,” said IFB President Philip Nelson.  “These ag summits bring together trusted experts and practical resources to help farmers have important conversations about their finances, their well-being and how to preserve their farm legacy for the next generation.”
“It’s no secret that the farm economy has been tough, especially for crop producers,” said Widmar.  “What’s often overlooked is how we got here and how farmers should position their business.  It’s important for producers to be specific about the unique risks and challenges their operations face and to connect those realities to broader market trends and decisions to be made in 2026.”
Kline will discuss estate and succession planning for farmers.  He will review the key components of a strong succession plan and will review the key steps to take without feeling overwhelmed by the process.  “Estate and succession planning works to keep Illinois farms in the hands of Illinois families,” said Kline.  “Death, disability or illness can change the farm operation overnight.  Estate and succession planning ensures the operation can continue and the family is protected.”
The closest Ag Summit location for Clay County farmers is on Wednesday, from 4 to 8:30 pm, at the Cedarhurst Center for the Arts in Mt. Vernon.
Attendees must RSVP online, at cfin.us/2026AgSummit.

title: PAPERLESS VEHICLE TITLES
full_story:
Paper vehicle titles will soon become a thing of the past as Illinois expands its statewide Electronic Lien and Titling program.
By July 1
st
, all financial institutions that process five or more liens annually in the state will be required to move to ELT.
The Illinois Secretary of State’s Office says going digital reduces mailing and storage costs, shortens processing time and provides real-time visibility into lien and title records.
“Moving to mandatory Electronic Lien and Titling is the next step in bringing Illinois’ vehicle services fully into the digital age,” Giannoulias said in a news release.  “This secure, paperless system cuts red tape for lenders and dealers, speeds up lien releases, accelerates the transfer process and better protects consumers.  What once took weeks or months can occur within hours.”
The Secretary of State’s Office says through the ELT system, lien and title records are transmitted directly and securely to its office and maintained electronically until the lien is satisfied.
Once a loan is paid off, banks, credit unions and dealers can release the title immediately.  Leaders say this benefits consumers as they won’t need to fill out paperwork, make in-person visits, and allows for faster sales, trade-ins or re-financing.
The system also looks to prevent “title washing” and fraudulent lien releases, protecting consumers and financial institutions.
Giannoulias says there is no enrollment or annual participation fee.  Statutory lien fees remain unchanged and will be collected at the point of sale, while any non-statutory service fees are assessed per transaction.
Lienholders can enroll through an approved ELT service provider or directly through the State ELT portal by contacting
.
The Secretary of State’s Office says financial institutions that process five or fewer liens per year are not required to participate in the ELT program.  Leaders say the threshold was intentionally set to avoid placing burden on small or low-volume lenders.  However, smaller institutions can opt in voluntarily and enroll with an approved ELT service provider if they choose.
The Illinois Secretary of State’s office first introduced ELT in 2024.  State leaders report the system has already helped cut customer wait times, improve accuracy and strengthen safeguards against fraud.
More information about the ELT can be found on the Secretary of State’s website.
The Secretary of State’s Office says the new requirement applies to lienholders, not individual vehicle owners.  For a private owner selling or transferring a vehicle they own outright, with no lien, there is no mandatory paperless option they must use.  Those transactions will continue to follow existing title transfer processes.  For more information about private party vehicle transactions, visit the Electronic Registration and Title system section on ilsos.gov.

title: LOUISVILLE VILLAGE BOARD MEETS
full_story:
The Louisville Village Board met Thursday night and moved quickly through their agenda.
As the meeting was called to order, Mayor Chris Rinehart asked and trustees approved the meeting agenda and past meeting minutes.  The first issue concerned the final pay order for the Pavillion Project.  Engineer Mike Bridges with Charleston Engineering of Olney presented the details of the request.  He recalled that Johannes Construction of Centralia removed the cracked concrete at Louisville’s new Pavillion on the courthouse square.  They replaced the damaged concrete with new materials from Flora Ready Mix, which is much closer than the original source.  Bridges indicated the new concrete has tested well and brings the OSLAD Grant program to a close.  He did note that there were two additions to the project, which increased the overall price.  He said metal trim for the roof added $4,000 to the price and two plumbing items increased the cost by $8,000.  Those items were a mop sink and a water fountain.   additions raised the cost of the final pay order to $41,889.  Some trustees bristled at the costs, but eventually the motion to approve passed on a unanimous vote.
Trustees next voted to approve the village bills for January and then briefly discussed the need to prepare for mowing this summer for village owned property.  Utilities Superintendent Troy Elwood stated that the properties needing mowed are the same as last year.  Members then voted to advertise for bids with a winning bidder chosen at a future meeting.
Mayor Rinehart called on Village Attorney Kyle Boose to update the board on his negotiations with Ameren concerning a franchise agreement.  Boose reported that he had struck an agreement with Ameren that includes changes that benefit the village by increasing the franchise fee from $5,000 to $8,000, annually.  Another change is the contract length.  The new agreement covers an eight-year period, rather than a much longer-term deal that Ameren had sought.  Trustees approved the new agreement without dissent.  A moment later, Boose presented information about the property at 930 Vandalia Rd., which the village is seeking to be cleaned up.  Boose reports the property has liens on it from the State of Illinois and there is a mortgage on the property as well.  He told the board that he will learn more as process unfolds and he will report back to them as it progresses.
The mayor stated that the Village of Louisville Policy Manual is in serious need of being updated.  He volunteered his time and stated that he and Clerk Leah Wetherholt could work on the manual.  It was then pointed out that there is a committee for that work, consisting of Chuck Smith, Craig Cliftron and Mary Frazier.  Mayor Rinehart said they could all work together on and that they need to make it priority to get it updated.  He suggested using the new policy manual just released by the Illinois Counties Risk Management Trust.  He says the village can just pick and choose the items they would like to see included in the new village document.  Rinehart offered to share the existing, outdated document with the whole board and members agreed that it was a good idea.
After a brief discussion about paying for a dumpster for residents use, village trustees are taking a wait and see attitude for the time being.  Members are torn between offering the Luttrell Dumpster for use by the community and seeing it filled with inappropriate materials by unknown parties.  The policy that was adopted in November will remain in place for the time being.  Residents can use the dumpster, but access is controlled by the village.  If Louisville residents need to place accepted items in the dumpster, call the village hall and talk to Utility Supt. Troy Elwood.
‘’The final item in open session was a discussion about offering increased pay for village employees that become certified for the various licenses that are required to operate the various entities that the village is required to operate.  That includes natural gas and water as the two most important.  Promises were made to an employee about obtaining licensure and being rewarded for his effort.  Trustees will likely discuss this further at a future meeting that would cover additional village employees.
In open time, which followed a brief closed session where no action was taken, Mayor Rinehart thanked village workers for their great effort at snow removal during the recent storms that deposited close a foot of snow in some areas.  He said they did a great job and thanked them for hard work.  That topic led Trustee Tim Davis to ask why village sidewalks weren’t cleared following the snowfall, particularly next to Route 45.  He said he’s seen numerous people walking on the highway because the sidewalks had not been shoveled and he fears someone will be hit by the nearby passing vehicles, especially when many seem to be wearing dark clothing.  Davis was referred to Louisville Village Ordinance 672 that prohibits the village from removing snow from sidewalks.  If the village were to remove snow and someone was injured, the village would be liable.  Removing snow from sidewalks is the responsibility of the property owner.  Next, Mayor Rinehart reported that a couple had purchased the Springfield Medical Clinic building on the courthouse square and has some as yet unannounced plans for the location.
Prior to adjourning, the board heard from Mary Murphy with Growls and Meows Veterinary Clinic in Cisne was in attendance on behalf of the Southern Illinois Critter Fixers.  The group is a non-profit organization that seeks to control the stray and feral cat population in the area.  They participate in what is referred to TNR, or Trap, Neuter and Return.  Theirs is a long-term solution to solve the cat overpopulation problem.  The village gave funds to the group in the past to help them get started.  Murphy presented a document that shows the work they’ve completed.  In Louisville, they’ve spayed or neutered 41 cats that prevents an estimated 600 cats from being born each year.  Murphy thanked the village for their contribution and thanked the other contributors from Louisville that are helping them to accomplish their mission.
So far, Louisville and its residents have contributed $3,335 to their cause.  To learn more about Southern Illinois Critter Fixers, call Mary Murphy at 618-599-6035.
With all business complete, the meeting adjourned.

title: MARION COUNTY ACCIDENT
full_story:
Wednesday night a Louisville resident was involved in a 2 car wreck east of Salem.
A vehicle driven by 43-year-old Derek Hilderbrand of Louisville hit the rear of a vehicle driven by 55-year-old Sherrie Robinson of Mt. Vernon.  Robinson had slowed to make a turn.  84-year-old Dora Duncan of Salem was a passenger in the Robinson vehicle.
All three were checked on the scene and refused hospital treatment.  The accident was reported at 6:47 pm Wednesday.

title: TAKE BACK ILLINOIS TOUR
full_story:
Gubernatorial candidate Darren Bailey, and his running mate Aaron Del Mar, are scheduling stops in the area starting Thursday.
The candidates will appear at the Poderosa Steakhouse in Vandalia from 9 to 10 am.  Then at the Milk House in Greenville from Noon to 1 pm.  From there they move to Salem where they will appear at the Freedom Church from 3 to 4 pm.  They end Thursday with an appearance at Skateland in Fairfield from 6 to 7 pm.  On Friday the tour makes appearances at the Lumberyard in West Salem from 9 to 10 am, and at Steve Jones Hardware in Salem from 3 to 4 pm.

title: SPAY & NEUTER AWARENESS MONTH
full_story:
February is Spay & Neuter Awareness Month, and Clip and Tip Strays (C.A.T.S.) marked the occasion, by helping 21 cats from Clay County get spayed and neutered at its low-cost clinic day held Tuesday, February 10
th
, in Flora.
Since launching monthly clinic days in November, the local nonprofit has now helped 89 cats receive sterilization surgery, improving their lives, and preventing generations of unwanted litters.
Surgeries were performed by licensed traveling veterinarian Dr. Meghann Jerden at Wags and Wash Salon, in Flora.  C.A.T.S. volunteers assisted with check-ins, discharges, and kept the clinic running smoothly.
Founder and Chairperson Cat Osterholtz, who also owns Wags and Wash Salon, recently shared an exciting milestone for the organization.  “We are thrilled to announce that C.A.T.S. has officially received its licensed nonprofit status.  We welcome volunteers and donors to partner with us in reducing cat homelessness and preventing the needless suffering of unwanted litters in our communities.”
C.A.T.S. Board Member and Treasurer Belinda Rueter emphasized the affordability of the program.  “Thanks to Dr. Jerden’s partnership, surgery rates are just $50 for a neuter and $80 for a spay.  That includes rabies vaccination for cats four months and older. We hope more cat owners and stray cat caretakers will take advantage of our low-cost monthly clinic days.”
Through teamwork, compassion, and community support, C.A.T.S. continues making progress toward a future with healthier feline lives and fewer homeless litters being born across Clay County.
Clip and Tip Strays (C.A.T.S.) is a passionate, volunteer-powered nonprofit based in Flora, dedicated to improving the lives of community cats.  Through fundraising and hands-on efforts, the group supports Trap-Neuter-Release (TNR); a proven, humane, and cost-effective approach to reducing the feral and stray cat population throughout Clay County.  Beyond clinic days, C.A.T.S. equips local cat owners and caretakers with traps and carriers to safely capture and transport cats for sterilization, making it easier for the community to be part of the solution.
To stay updated on upcoming Clinic Days and events, follow Clip and Tip Strays on Facebook.  You can also call or text 618-662-3837, or reach them by mail at PO Box 23, Flora, IL 62839.
Photo Caption:
C.A.T.S. volunteers at the February 10th spay & neuter clinic day in Flora: Cat Osterholtz, Belinda Rueter, Olivia Rueter and Holly Cooper.

title: FMH NEW MOBILE IMAGING
full_story:
Fairfield Memorial Hospital announced the addition of a new Shimadzu MX8 Mobile Digital Radiography Imaging System, further strengthening their diagnostic imaging capabilities and reinforcing their commitment to high-quality, patient-centered care.
The Shimadzu MX8 is equipped with Canon’s Built-in Automatic Exposure Control Assistance (BiAA) technology, an advanced feature designed to support consistent image quality while optimizing radiation exposure.  This innovative technology allows the detector to monitor exposure levels in real time and communicate directly with the X-ray generator, eliminating the need for external sensors and supporting reliable imaging in a variety of clinical settings, including bedside exams.
For patients, this advanced system provides clearer, more precise images with minimized radiation exposure and shorter exam times.  Faster image acquisition and intelligent processing reduce the need for repeat imaging, creating a more efficient and comfortable diagnostic experience.  For clinical teams, the MX8 enhances workflow, improves diagnostic confidence, and supports timely, accurate decision-making, allowing staff to focus more fully on patient care.
This new imaging system represents a meaningful investment in modern healthcare technology at Fairfield Memorial Hospital.  By continuing to adopt advanced diagnostic tools, FMH remains dedicated to improving clinical outcomes and enhancing the overall patient experience.
Fairfield Memorial Hospital worked with Electromek Diagnostic Systems during the procurement and installation of the MX8, and we appreciate their technical support throughout this process.
The addition of the Shimadzu MX8 Mobile Digital Radiography System marks another step forward in Fairfield Memorial Hospital’s mission to provide exceptional care close to home.
For more information about this new imaging capability, contact Fairfield Memorial Hospital Diagnostic Imaging Department at 618-847-8249.

title: REQUEST DENIED
full_story:
Aydreian D. Hooper’s request for a reduction of her sentence for the 2024 hot car death of her toddler son was denied on Tuesday in Wayne County Circuit Court.
Judge Thomas J. Dinn ruled that “After consideration of exhibits and arguments, the court finds no reason to disturb its original sentence and the motion to reconsider is denied.”  Hooper drew a 10-year prison sentence after pleading guilty in December of 2024 to a Class-3 felony charge of child endangerment causing a death.  In return for the plea, the state dropped charges of involuntary manslaughter of a family member, reckless conduct causing bodily harm and child endangerment.
Hooper is currently serving her sentence at the Logan Woman’s Prison in Lincoln.  Prison records show she will be eligible for parole in 4 years.

title: FERTILIZER PRICES MIXED
full_story:
DTN retail fertilizer prices for the first week of February 2026 are evenly mixed.
Four fertilizers were slightly lower in price compared to last month while the other four were slightly higher.  DTN designates a significant move as anything 5% or more.
One fertilizer with a sizeable price increase was urea.  The nitrogen fertilizer was 5% higher compared to last month with an average price of $596/ton.
The other higher-priced nutrients were DAP with an average price of $851/ton, MAP $879/ton and potash $488/ton.
The four fertilizers with slightly lower prices were 10-34-0 with an average price of $665/ton, anhydrous $860/ton, UAN28 $410/ton and UAN32 $464/ton.
On a price per pound of nitrogen basis, the average urea price was $0.65/lb.N, anhydrous $0.52/lb.N, UAN28 $0.73/lb.N and UAN32 $0.73/lb.N.
DTN Ag Policy Editor Chris Clayton reported Tuesday that two corn producer organizations have sent letters to US Attorney General Pam Bondi to explain what the Justice Department is doing to pursue possible antitrust action in the fertilizer industry.
The president of the Texas Corn Producers Association (TCPA) wrote Bondi requesting a formal status report about a Justice Department investigation into fertilizer prices and market concentration.  This letter follows a letter written last week by the president of the Iowa Corn Growers Association asking similar questions.
The letters reflect the growing frustration over the financial situation facing crop producers, who continue to see high input prices.  Fertilizer costs make up a high percentage of crop producers’ total input costs.
“As farmers work to maintain a stable, high-quality supply of food and feed for the nation, they are being pushed to the breaking point by unsustainable input costs,” TCPA stated.
Eight fertilizers are now higher in price compared to one year earlier: 10-34-0 by 5%, MAP 9%, potash 12%, both DAP and urea 14%, anhydrous 16%, UAN32 20% and UAN28 by 23%.

title: RIVERA FOUND FIT FOR TRIAL
full_story:
Arnold Rivera was found fit to stand trial on Tuesday for the murder of a 14-year-old girl in Fayette County.
The 43-year-old Rivera faces two counts of first-degree murder, as well as two counts of criminal sexual assault and counts of concealing a homicidal death.  The counts state that Rivera, who was a family member of the 14-year-old, is alleged to have committed an act of sexual penetration with the juvenile.  It also states that Rivera was a caretaker in a position of trust or supervision with the 14-year-old.  Both counts are Class 1 Felonies.  Rivera also faces 1 count of Concealment of a Homicidal Death for the November 14
th
murder.  That count is a Class 3 Felony.
Rivera is to go on trial on April 20
th
.  He is next due in court on March 24
th
.

title: IAA SCHOLARSHIPS AVAILABLE
full_story:
Sunday is the deadline to apply for more than $340,000 in scholarships available for agriculture students through the IAA Foundation.
“Offering scholarships that encourage students to explore degrees in agriculture related fields is a privilege,” said Jennifer Smith, IAA Foundation development manager.  “It is imperative that future agriculture leaders receive financial support so they can focus on their education and begin to build their career in agriculture.”
Agriculture students and Illinois Farm Bureau (IFB) members, spouses and dependents are eligible to apply for college scholarships offered by the IAA Foundation, Illinois Farm Bureau’s charitable arm.
Applications are now open for a variety of financial awards including the newly created Gene A. Daiber Scholarship, J. Lloyd and Elizabeth Broaddus Jones Scholarship, Joe and Sue Summerville Scholarship, Kenneth and Kay Engle Agriculture Scholarship, Pat Oaks Memorial Scholarship, and Paul Meints Scholarship.  Additionally, the IAA Foundation offers scholarships on behalf of Prairie Farms Dairy, Illinois Pork Producers Association and several family scholarships established to honor legacies and loved ones.
Scholarships are awarded based on involvement in extra-curricular activities, community service, academic performance, leadership experiences and an essay.  Previous winners of an IAA Foundation scholarship are eligible to apply again if the individual scholarship allows.
A full listing of available scholarships and eligibility guidelines is available at iaafoundation.org.  Applications must be completed online by Sunday.  For more information, contact your county Farm Bureau, the IAA Foundation at 309-557-2232, or email Jennifer Smith at
.
The mission of the IAA Foundation, Illinois Farm Bureau’s charitable arm, is to fund education, research and charitable activities that benefit Illinois farm families and agriculture.

full_story:
Tax season is here, and the Better Business Bureau wants to ensure Americans have the tools they need to avoid tax scams and identity theft.
From phishing to phone calls, the B-B-B reports that scammers are getting more sophisticated each year, and this year is no exception.
