title: HOME FIRE SAFETY
full_story:
As winter weather brings extreme cold across Illinois, fire safety officials are urging residents to use extra caution when heating their homes.  Frigid temperatures often lead people to rely more heavily on heating systems and alternative heat sources, which can increase the risk of home fires and carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning if proper safety precautions are not followed.
In 2024, Illinois fire departments responded to 9,860 carbon monoxide (CO) related calls across the state.  According to the National Carbon Monoxide Awareness Association, emergency rooms across the US see more than 100,000 visits each year due to CO exposure.  Tragically, over 14,000 people are hospitalized annually, and approximately 1,200 people die each year from carbon monoxide poisoning, a number that continues to rise.
Illinois State Fire Marshal Michele Pankow said, “During winter storms and blasts of frigid arctic air, we see a rise in home fires and carbon monoxide incidents due to the increased use of heating equipment, fireplaces, generators, and alternative heat sources.  Many of these emergencies are preventable with a few simple safety steps.  Working smoke alarms and CO alarms save lives.  As temperatures drop, taking a few minutes to review winter safety practices can make all the difference.”
Home heating equipment is a leading cause of residential fires during the winter months.  OSFM recommends the following fire safety tips.  Keep all heat sources at least three feet away from anything that can burn, including furniture, curtains, and bedding.  Never use ovens, stoves, grills, or portable fuel-burning devices to heat your home.  Turn off space heaters before leaving the room or going to bed.  Have chimneys, fireplaces, and heating systems inspected and cleaned annually by a qualified professional.  And Ensure smoke alarms are installed on every level of the home and inside sleeping areas and test them monthly.
Residents are also encouraged to have an emergency plan in place during winter storms and extreme cold, including identifying warming centers in their community and checking on elderly neighbors or those with limited mobility.
For more winter weather fire safety and carbon monoxide safety information, visit sfm.illinois.gov or follow OSFM on facebook and twitter.

title: COMMERCIAL TRUCK RENEWAL
full_story:
The Secretary of State’s office is making it easier and faster for Illinois-based commercial trucking firms to renew their federal registration credentials by expanding online filing and payment options.
Companies with fewer than 250 vehicles can now complete International Registration Plan (IRP) renewals online by uploading their IRS-issued Heavy Vehicle Use Tax (HVUT) Form 2290 and submitting payment electronically.  Once required documents are confirmed, registration credentials will be emailed within three business days; eliminating the need for an in-person visit to the Dirksen DMV in Springfield.
The new system also includes real-time mileage checks, which flags errors or inconsistencies immediately, allowing customers to correct them on the spot without having to contact the Secretary of State’s office.  The system automatically determines whether estimated or actual mileage is acceptable, further streamlining the process.  Registrants may re-enter the application as many times as needed to renew additional vehicles without requesting a system reset.
Carriers can pay renewal fees using a credit card or e-check.  For large online payments, customers are encouraged to confirm with their bank to avoid delays and returned check fees.
This online option applies only to renewals of existing vehicles already registered to a firm.  Registering new vehicles, updating existing units or obtaining new plates will continue to be handled through the IRP Supplement process, which opens April 1
st
.  Invoices can still be generated for customers who prefer to pay by mail or in person, and in-person customers are advised to bring printed documents to avoid processing delays.

title: ILLINOIS RIFL ACT
full_story:
ILLINOIS RIFL ACT
(1/26/26)
As Illinois lawmakers convene for the 2026 legislative session, House Bill 3320, Responsibility in Firearm Legislation Act, is quickly emerging as one of Governor JB Pritzker’s most controversial gun-control proposals, drawing sharp criticism from gun-rights advocates and strong support from Democratic lawmakers focused on gun violence prevention.
House Bill 3320 would require firearm manufacturers operating in Illinois to obtain a new state permit and pay fees tied to the estimated cost of gun violence.
Aaron Dorr of the Illinois Firearms Association in a recent video said Pritzker’s RIFL Act is probably the most dangerous gun control bill Illinoisans have ever seen, and it already has 35 co-sponsors.
“For the first year of implementation, these commies have set the total cost of so-called ‘gun violence’ at $866 million.  In other words, the more popular a gun manufacturer is, the more guns they sell, the more they get shaken down by the state of Illinois.  This is straight-up economic warfare against firearms manufacturers, designed to drive them out of the state,” said Dorr.
Supporters of the bill argue it is a response to the financial burden gun violence places on taxpayers.  State Senator Robert Peters, a Chicago Democrat and longtime gun-control advocate, said Illinois residents are already paying the price for firearm-related injuries and deaths.
“Illinois taxpayers pay billions for gun injuries each year, from hospital bills to emergency response, lost wages to rehabilitation,” Peters said.  “With the RIFL Act, we are demanding the firearm manufacturing industry share in these public costs with us.”
The legislation would create a new state permit for firearm manufacturers operating in Illinois.  Under the proposal, manufacturers would be charged annual licensing fees based on their market share and the state’s estimated cost of gun violence.
Peters said federal protections have long shielded manufacturers from financial accountability.
“Since the Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act, firearm manufacturers have been shielded from lawsuits and the consequences of their for-profit activity, leaving taxpayers to effectively subsidize the negative effects of the firearm industry.  The RIFL Act aims to fund survivors and community violence intervention,” Peters said.  “It shifts costs from working-class families to an industry that profits an estimated $20 billion a year.”
Under HB 3320, funds collected from manufacturers would be used to compensate individuals defined as victims of firearm injuries.  Eligible expenses include medical care, mental health services, lost wages, relocation costs and funeral expenses.
Critics argue the bill’s definition of “victim” is overly broad. Dorr warned that the language does not distinguish between innocent victims and individuals injured while committing crimes.
“There’s no carve-out that says they have to be the victim of a crime,” Dorr said.  “A person shot while committing a robbery could be treated as a victim under this act.”
The bill also includes penalties for noncompliance.  Manufacturers who violate the act could face civil fines of up to $1 million per month, while firearm retailers could be fined $10,000 per violation for selling products from unpermitted manufacturers.
Dorr said those penalties are intended to dismantle the firearms industry in Illinois.
“That’s designed to collapse the entire firearms supply chain in Illinois,” Dorr said.  “Manufacturers, dealers, and ultimately gun owners are all targets.”
Although HB 3320 did not receive a vote last session, its growing list of co-sponsors has raised concerns among opponents that the measure could advance this year.

title: WINTER STORM STRIKES CLAY COUNTY
full_story:
WINTER STORM
(1/26/26)
Clay County was blanketed in at least 8 inches of snow over the weekend.  Officially, WNOI recorded 9 inches of snow for Flora and Clay County, which equates to roughly 8/10’s of an inch of precipitation.
Steve Lewis with Clay County ESDA said Sunday that the roads were still in bad condition, especially country roads.  But luckily, people were staying home.  ESDA has been put to service ferrying workers to and from Clay County Hospital.
According to Sheriff Andy Meyers, secondary roads are snow covered and drifted in several locations.  Conditions on area highways also have many slick spots.  Any unnecessary travel is strongly discouraged.
An Extreme Cold Warning has been issued for a good portion of Central and East-Central Illinois from midnight to 12 pm on Monday.

title: NORTH CLAY BOARD MEETING
full_story:
The North Clay School Board met in regular session on Wednesday night.
Kaitlin Zink, Elementary/Junior High Physical Education teacher spoke on behalf of the PE Department regarding the positive impact of the new facilities.  She highlighted how the expanded space has fostered a safer environment and allowed for more structured educational units across a wider variety of activities.
Superintendent Keith Price discussed what a school district’s Health Life Safety Survey is and the proposed amendment.  School districts have Health Life Safety Surveys that identify specific areas of school facilities that are in need of repair or improvement.  In order for an item to be on the survey, it must be approved by an architect, the Regional Office of Education and the Illinois State Board of Education.  Two items added include patchwork and recoating of the outer shell of the main high school building, and an electrical power upgrade for the high school industrial arts shop.
The board approved the purchase of a new drivers education vehicle.
In personnel matters the board hired Andrew Conrad as Head High School Bass Fishing Coach, and Dustin Smith as high school track and field head coach.  They also approved Gavin Hosselton as a high school boys basketball volunteer coach, and Malorie Craig as High School Volleyball Head Coach.  Resignations were accepted from Neal Conard as Head High School Bass Fishing Coach, effective immediately, and Amanda Bailey as head high school Track and Field Coach.

title: IDOA SENIOR HALL OF FAME
full_story:
The Illinois Department on Aging (IDoA) is seeking nominations for the 2026 induction class of the Senior Illinoisans Hall of Fame, which honors the accomplishments of Illinois residents aged 65 and older.
Each year, four older adults are inducted into the Hall of Fame for their work in the arts, sports, and entertainment; community service; education; or the labor force.  Anyone may nominate an older adult for consideration.
To be eligible for nomination to the Hall of Fame, nominees must be at least 65 years old at the time of nomination; and a current Illinois resident or a previous resident of Illinois for most of their life.
Posthumous nominations are also accepted, provided the nominee was 65 or older and living in Illinois at the time of death.
To guarantee consideration for the 2026 induction class, nominations must be submitted on or before June 2
nd
.  Nominators of new Hall of Fame inductees are expected to participate in an award ceremony honoring their nominee and highlighting their accomplishments.

title: Extreme Cold Weather Advisory & Energy Cost Reminder
full_story:
Our region is experiencing extremely cold temperatures, and they are predicted to remain dangerously low until at least Monday.
For safety, avoid prolonged exposure to extreme cold and remember to check on elderly neighbors or those who may need assistance.
We also wanted to let our residents know that during this prolonged cold spell, natural gas bills are likely to be higher than normal. This is due to two factors:
Higher natural gas market prices during extreme cold (rates are set by the daily gas market and not controlled by the City)
Increased gas usage as homes and businesses work harder to stay warm.
There are steps residents can take to help reduce energy use where it is safe to do so:
Lower your thermostat by even one degree — small adjustments can make a noticeable difference on your bill
Close blinds and curtains at night to reduce heat loss
Seal drafts around doors and windows
Avoid using space heaters unsafely (plug them directly into the outlet & give them space)
Make sure vents and registers are not blocked
Dress in warm layers indoors when possible

full_story:

title: WEATHER SPOTTER TRAINING
full_story:
The National Weather Service is offering their annual severe weather spotter training on March 19
th
at 6:00 pm.  The class will be held at Frontier Community College.
Severe storm spotters are a VITAL part of the severe weather warning process.  Spotters provide critical, and potentially, lifesaving information to their communities and surrounding locations – and to National Weather Service (NWS) forecasters who are using these reports to help issue warnings and keep the public updated during severe weather events.
The in-person training covers severe weather hazards including thunderstorms and tornadoes, safety concerns, planning for and anticipating severe thunderstorms, general storm structure and movement, and identification of important storm features.
This year’s program offers more interactive portions of the sessions.  The session will last about 2 hours and are free and open to the public.  Registration is required and is available at wewather.gov/pah/spottertraining or scan the QR Code on the event flyers.

title: CLMT EVENTS START IN EFFINGHAM
full_story:
Livestock operations are strengthened by having certified individuals on staff.  Certification helps minimize environmental impacts through increased awareness of regulations and proper manure nutrient management.  Anyone responsible for managing a facility can benefit from increasing their knowledge and expertise.
Farm operators and staff can get certified through one of University of Illinois Extension and the Illinois Department of Agriculture’s (IDOA) 2026 Certified Livestock Manager Training or CLMT workshops, kicking off Tuesday, February 3
rd
in Effingham.
Depending on the size of an operation, livestock manager training certification is required for many Illinois production livestock facilities.  A certified livestock manager is a full-time employee who is familiar with the farm’s manure management system and is located within one hour’s driving distance of the farm, accessible by phone when needed.
The Effingham event will be held at the University of Illinois Extension Office, at 1209 North Wenthe Avenue.  Find facility and size requirements described online at go.illinois.edu/CLMT.  Pre-registration is required to attend an in-person workshop.  Class size is limited.
The workshop will open at 8:30 am, and training will begin at 9 am.  The training lasts 3.5 hours, and IDOA staff will administer the exam after the training.  The Illinois Extension training fee is $40, and IDOA’s certification fee is $30.  To be certified, all participants need to attend the entire workshop.
Training covers a range of topics related to the operation, management, and utilization of livestock waste and waste facilities.  The training manual used is the Livestock and Poultry Environmental Stewardship Curriculum.  It is available online at go.illinois.edu/manual.
For those unable to attend, online training and testing are available year-round at go.illinois.edu/CLMT, following the same format as the in-person workshops.  Those needing certification for over 1,000 animal units may take the test online following the training.
If you have program questions or need a reasonable accommodation to participate, please contact Stanley Solomon, Illinois Extension educator at
or by phone at 815-235-4125.

title: EARTHQUAKE TUESDAY
full_story:
An earthquake shook parts of the Land of Lincoln early Tuesday morning.
The United States Geological Survey (USGS) said a magnitude 3.8 earthquake was recorded at 1:27 am Central time Tuesday, a little more than 5 miles below ground.
The USGS said the epicenter was near Ohlman, Illinois. Ohlman is located in Christian County, about 40 miles southeast of Springfield or about 12 miles southeast of Taylorville.
People reported feeling shaking from the earthquake in St. Louis.  USGS states there was light to moderate shaking.  An earthquake of this magnitude can often be felt but very rarely would cause damage.

title: BLOOD SHORTAGE
full_story:
The American Red Cross is facing a severe blood shortage, reporting supply has dropped by 35%.
The Red Cross said requests from hospitals are exceeding the available supply of blood.
People falling ill with the flu may be keeping donors away from donation centers, slowing the national effort to rebuild blood supply.  Winter weather also impedes donation efforts with people choosing to stay off the roads and indoors.
The Red Cross is asking health individuals to book an appointment to give blood or platelets by using the Blood Donor App, visiting RedCrossBlood.org or calling 1-800-RED CROSS.
The next blood drive in Flora will be on February 12
th
at the Flora Church of the Nazarene; appointments are currently available but there are only 4 power red donation appointments available.

title: TAX SEASON
full_story:
The Illinois Department of Revenue (IDOR) announced that it will begin accepting 2026 individual income tax returns on Monday, the same day the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) opens the federal filing season.  The deadline to file Illinois returns is Wednesday, April 15
th
.
IDOR encourages taxpayers to file their returns electronically and choose direct deposit to receive refunds as quickly and securely as possible.
IDOR Director David Harris said, “We want the tax filing process to be as smooth and stress-free as possible.  Before filing, you should make sure you have all income documents, such as W-2s and 1099s.  Filing online, reviewing information carefully, and submitting your returns early can help avoid delays and get you any refunds you may be entitled to sooner.”
During the 2025 filing season, IDOR received over 6.3 million individual income tax returns.  About 5.75 million, or 91.3 percent, were filed electronically.  Taxpayers who file accurate returns electronically and select direct deposit can typically receive their refunds in about four weeks.
MyTax Illinois is IDOR’s free online filing option that allows taxpayers to file with or without an account.  The system guides users through a simple question-and-answer process, performs calculations automatically, and reduces errors by using prepopulated information when available.  In addition to filing, MyTax Illinois allows users to, Make payments, Respond to department inquiries, Check the status of refunds via Where’s My Refund?, and Look up IL-PINs, estimated tax payments, and Form 1099-G information.
Taxpayers may also file using tax software, a tax professional, or paper Form IL-1040.
IDOR reminds taxpayers to review their eligibility for tax credits that can reduce the amount of tax owed or increase a refund.  Commonly claimed credits include the Illinois Earned Income Tax Credit, the Property Tax Credit, and the K–12 Education Expense Credit, among others.
“Tax credits can put more money back in your pocket,” Harris said.  “Taking time to review the credits you qualify for can make a real difference.”
The United States Postal Service (USPS) announced changes to postmarks that could impact tax filings in 2026.  The USPS postmark now shows the date of the first automated processing operation instead of when a piece of mail was dropped off.  This modification could impact time-sensitive documents such as tax returns and payments.
USPS will continue to add manual postmarks upon request at their offices.  IDOR encourages taxpayers who mail their returns and tax payments to mail those items earlier than they typically would to ensure timely delivery.
“If you plan to mail your return or payment, don’t wait until the last day,” Harris stressed.  “Sending it early or requesting a manual postmark at the post office can help protect you from late penalties.”
IDOR provides assistance by phone for tax-related questions, with automated options for checking refund status, identifying IL-PINs, or accessing estimated payments.
Taxpayers may call 1-800-732-8866 or 217-782-3336. Free language assistance is available for Limited English Proficiency (LEP) individuals.
For the most up-to-date information, forms, schedules, and instructions for the 2026 tax season, visit tax.illinois.gov.

title: ILLINOIS CALLS FOR YEAR-ROUND E15
full_story:
The State of Illinois is again calling on the United States Congress and the Trump administration to require year-round sales of E15 fuel.  Earlier this year, Governor JB Pritzker sent a letter to Congressional leadership on November 4, 2025, urging nationwide, year-round E15.
“Agriculture is the number one industry in Illinois.  Our farmers feed the world, and they have the potential to fuel it as well.  As Trump’s tariffs hurt farmers nationwide and rising costs put strain on American families, Congress must require permanent, year-round E15, said Governor JB Pritzker.  “E15 enhances our nation’s energy supply, helps the economy, and supports a cleaner environment all at once.  Year-round E15 is not optional — it’s essential.  That’s why I was the first Governor in the corn belt to sound the alarm for Congress in November.  I once again urge the federal government to act in favor of our farmers and the environment.”
Under current law, E15 access during the summer driving season has relied on temporary emergency waivers.  These stopgap measures provide only brief relief and fall short of a stable, long-term solution.
Illinois is the second largest producer of corn in the nation.  With corn production at record highs – the USDA crop estimate puts corn crop estimates above 17 billion bushels for the first time, up from 14.9 billion bushels in 2024 – the surplus inventory drives prices down, hurting farmers already struggling to break even amid rising input costs.  Corn prices hit the lowest price since August after the USDA made its announcement.
A year-round requirement for E15 would increase demand for corn by 2 billion bushels a year, according to a new report from the Renewable Fuels Association.
While ethanol use supports jobs, lowers fuel costs and reduces emissions, federal regulations continue to block E15 sales during critical summer months, creating unnecessary uncertainty for farmers.
“Illinois is a national leader in corn and ethanol production. Year-round E15 would keep energy dollars in the Midwest, reduce reliance on foreign oil, and cut harmful emissions without additional cost to taxpayers,” said Jerry Costello II, Director of the Illinois Department of Agriculture.
Allowing nationwide, year-round use of American ethanol is a practical solution that strengthens the energy supply, reduces costs for consumers, and provides the long-term certainty that Illinois farmers deserve.
“Illinois farmers cannot afford to do business.  The best solution is a stronger economy,” said US Senator Dick Durbin.  “First, the President must stop these trade wars that are damaging our top farm export markets.  Second, Congress must pass permanent E15, which will immediately help farm families, while cutting the cost of gasoline for everyone by up to 30 cents a gallon.  As a member of the Senate Agriculture Committee, I will fight to get E15 finished now.”
“Illinois farmers are the backbone of our economy and the stewards of America’s food and fuel supply.  Year-round E15 isn’t just an agricultural issue; it’s an economic, environmental, and national security imperative.  By adopting a permanent, nationwide E15 standard, we can lower costs for families, strengthen rural communities, and reduce our dependence on foreign oil.  Congress must deliver the certainty our farmers and consumers deserve,” said Rep. Jonathan Jackson.
“I have been fighting in Congress for several years to secure year-round, nationwide access to E-15, including cosponsoring the Nationwide Consumer and Fuel Retailer Choice Act,” said Rep. Robin Kelly.  “While temporary waivers for midwestern states have helped maintain the ethanol industry, it is past time to allow the sale of year-round E-15 across the country.  At a time when affordability is top of mind for Illinoisans, homegrown biofuels will lower fuel prices, reduce emissions, and provide support for our farmers as they navigate President Trump’s challenging tariffs.”
“Illinois farmers are producing more than ever, but Washington’s stop-and-go approach to E15 keeps holding them back,” said Congressman Raja Krishnamoorthi.  “Making E15 available year-round would strengthen our energy supply, lower costs at the pump, and provide the certainty corn growers need to stay competitive.  It’s a practical, pro-farmer solution—and it’s time for federal action.”
“I have long been a strong advocate for year-round E15, having seen firsthand the benefits it delivers to consumers at the pump and to the farmers in my district,” said Congresswoman Nikki Budzinski.  “As co-chair of the Biofuels Caucus in Congress, I will continue leading the charge for federal legislation that provides a permanent solution and long-term certainty for our growers.”
“Year-round E15 is a win for Illinois farmers and for families feeling the pinch at the pump.  It creates steady demand for our corn, supports rural jobs, and gives drivers a cleaner, more affordable fuel choice,” said Congressman Eric Sorensen.  “Congress and the administration need to act so producers and consumers can count on certainty, not short-term fixes.”

title: KINMUNDY MAN SENTENCED
full_story:
A 33-year-old Kinmundy man was sentenced to 13 years in prison after pleading guilty to indecent solicitation of a child, aggravated criminal sexual abuse and grooming.  Daniel Belfiore originally faced eight counts of sexual misconduct involving the same teenage girl who was described by police at the time of his arrest as a family friend.
Belfiore was sentenced to five years in prison on both the indecent solicitation of a child and aggravated criminal sexual abuse charges and three years on a grooming charge.  Judge Mark Stedelin ordered all the sentences to be served consecutively.
Belfiore gave a statement of allocution, and the victim and her father both provided victim impact statements.
At an earlier plea hearing, five other counts of aggravated criminal sexual abuse were dropped.

title: TEXT SCAMS
full_story:
Illinois Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias is warning Illinoisans to lookout for text message scams claiming to be from the “Illinois State Department of Motor Vehicles.”  The messages threaten to suspend vehicle registration and driving privileges, while falsely claiming that enforcement actions began January 17
th
.  The Illinois Secretary of State’s office never sends text messages requesting personal or financial information.
These text messages are phishing, or “smishing,” attempts designed to trick residents into giving up personal or financial information.  Recipients should not respond to these messages or open any links found in unsolicited texts and emails.
The Illinois Secretary of State’s office does not send text messages demanding payment for traffic fines or requesting driver’s license or vehicle registration information.  The only text messages sent by the office are appointment reminders for scheduled DMV appointments.
“Scammers are constantly trying to find new ways to cheat Illinoisans out of their personal information and hard-earned money,” Giannoulias said.  “These deceptive scams are unfortunately an increasingly prevalent threat in our modern society, and they’re coming from many sources, including phone calls, text messages and email communications.  I encourage everyone to remain vigilant, avoid engaging with these messages and report scams to help protect themselves and others.”
Illinoisans are encouraged to report scam attempts to the Federal Trade Commission by visiting reportfraud.ftc.gov.

title: POSTAL CHANGES FOR MAIL IN VOTING
full_story:
1/19/26
New postal service changes to postmarking and transportation rules could disrupt mail-in voting in the 2026 election, Illinois county clerks warn.
Ahead of the March primary election, county clerks are telling voters not to rely on past processes and to mail their ballots as early as possible, no later than one week before Election Day.
Clerks from around the state discussed how to educate voters at the annual Illinois Association of County Clerks and Recorders Conference on Thursday in East Peoria.
One new rule, which took effect December 24
th
, states that the date a postmark is applied to a piece of mail may not reflect the day it was received by the Postal Service.
Currently, 14 states, including Illinois, will accept mail-in ballots if they are received within a certain period after Election Day if they are postmarked on or before Election Day.
Clerks warned that uncertainty about when ballots will now be postmarked necessitates voters to act earlier.  The way postmarks are applied is not changing, the USPS says.  Mail is only postmarked at distribution centers, and that will remain the same.
But in an effort to improve mail delivery efficiency, some localities’ mail may be sent to a different distribution center than in the past, which can increase the amount of time it takes for the USPS to receive and then postmark mail at these centers.
“It’s a question mark of when will it actually get through a distribution center.  So I’m advising my voters to make sure that they get their vote-by-mail ballot in the mail no less than a week before Election Day,” John Ackerman, the Tazewell County clerk, said.
Voters can also request a manual postmark from their local post office or drop off their ballot at the election official’s office.
But if election officials can’t rely on postmarks to reflect accurate dates, a number of mail-in ballots that were mailed prior to Election Day may not be counted at all clerks said.
Ballots also will no longer be automatically considered priority mail, increasing the amount of time it will take to deliver the mail.
These changes will be most felt during the recount process, when candidates are “scrambling,” Ackerman said.
The clerks generally agreed this could change the outcome of a race.
Clerks also said they are concerned about changes impacting voter trust in elections, especially because voter guidance is now going to be different depending on the county’s location and distribution center.
In the past, when this potential change was proposed, the clerks said they were able to speak to federal lawmakers to advocate for its reversal.
In late September 2025, a delegation of clerks traveled to Washington, DC, to meet with lawmakers and staff about changes to federal funding for election infrastructure and learned lawmakers didn’t know about the potential changes, Ackerman said.
“They were all unaware that this change was going to take effect.  They were unaware, in my opinion, of the impacts it would have on vote by mail,” he said.
This time, however, clerks didn’t know the changes were proposed until days before they were implemented.
To be sure your vote has been counted, voters can call their county clerk’s office, or some counties offer ballot tracking online.
County clerks emphasized that voting by mail is still safe and secure, but it might take more work and planning.

title: McConnell secures $541M for Kentucky in federal funding
full_story:
McConnell secures $541M for Kentucky in federal funding
Digital Content Manager
Jan 15, 2026
6 hrs ago
Copy article link
WASHINGTON, D.C. (WEVV) -- U.S. Sen. Mitch McConnell of Kentucky announced the Senate's passage of a federal funding bill that secures more than $540 million for Kentucky priorities. The bill, which focuses on areas such as Commerce-Justice-Science, Interior-Environment, and Energy-Water, now awaits President Trump's signature.
The funding includes $70 million for the University of Louisville's Center for Bioscience and $35 million for the University of Kentucky's Healthy Kentucky Research Building No. 2. "This federal funding is an important investment in research infrastructure at UofL and UK," McConnell said.
The bill allocates $2.5 million for a new cybercrime training facility in Madisonville and $352,000 for law enforcement equipment in Warren County. "These federal investments will equip Kentucky's law enforcement with the tools and training they need to keep our communities safe," McConnell said.
Additionally, $340 million is set aside for environmental remediation at the Paducah Gaseous Diffusion Plant. "These federal investments deliver long-overdue cleanup at the Paducah Gaseous Diffusion Plant while positioning the site for the future," McConnell said.
The funding also includes $21.281 million for the Rough River Dam Safety Modification Project and $600,000 for an erosion study at Columbus-Belmont State Park. Investments in water infrastructure, such as $9.256 million for a water treatment plant in Edmonson County, are also part of the package. "These critical federal investments in water and wastewater infrastructure will protect public health and ensure Kentucky communities can continue to grow," McConnell said.
The bill supports recreational areas with $7.45 million for Land Between the Lakes National Recreation Area and $1 million for improvements at Green River National Wildlife Refuge. "Investing in Land Between the Lakes and the Green River National Wildlife Refuge strengthens Kentucky's outdoor recreation and tourism opportunities," McConnell said.
Other priorities include $10.5 million in funding for invasive carp management in the lower Mississippi River Basin, funding for economic development initiatives, and for law enforcement support. The bill also ensures continued funding for a new federal prison in Letcher County and allocates $200 million for the Appalachian Regional Commission.

title: CLAY CITY SCHOOL BOARD MEETS
full_story:
(1/16/26) pg
The Clay City School Board met Thursday night in the district library and made quick work of a light agenda, but it did include a brief discussion about the topic of alternative school.
Board President Misty Lindeman called the meeting to order, and the roll was called with all members present.  The board approved the agenda and past meeting minutes.
Superintendent John Neubaum presented the Financial Report and noted that finances were pretty stable, except for an HVAC issue at the end of the year that cost the district around $15,000 to fix.  He also mentioned that the ISBE budget is being reduced and that will translate to belt tightening at schools across the state.  A motion was made to approve the financial report, and it was approved unanimously.
In informational items, Supt. Neubaum said there are 211 students enrolled at Clay City Schools.  He moved on to briefly comment on the Illinois School Report Card.  He said the state had changed how districts are rated in some regard.  Some schools that had achieved commendable status are now listed as not commendable and the change of descriptions was causing angst around the state.  Neubaum said ISBE normally just plows ahead despite concerns.  But this time they are conducting a listening tour to better understand the districts issues with the new system of ratings.  Supt. Neubaum also discussed the continuing issues with FOIA (Freedom of Information Act) Requests.  He says the district received a request from a law firm that specializes in suing Illinois school districts that redact names from documents.  He said the district’s law firm suggested that they deal with that particular FOIA request.
Principal Brian Wattles presented the student activity update.  He noted Pre-K students are preparing to hatch chickens in their hands on science experience.  Kindergarten students were preparing for the 100
th
day of School on January 27 and learning about the impact of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.  First grade students focused on their goal of earning 240 good grades and are earning a trip to The Scoop on Main for ice cream and studying about the legacy of Martin Lutrher King Jr.  Third grade students are working on division in math and reading both picture books and chapter books. Fourth graders are taking a new approach on Accelerated Reader assignments and look two complete two AR tests each week.  Sixth grade students are learning about Mediterranean Countries while seventh grade students are studying the founding of the 13 Original Colonies.  And eight graders are examining the differences between the North and South during the Industrial Revolution.  They also learned about sending professional emails.  Jr. high literature classes focused on non-fiction books.  At the high school, students completed CPR training and numerous students were recognized for their dedication and hard work.  Student Molly Lindeman was also recognized for performing the National Anthem at last weeks’ Clay City vs. North Clay basketball game.  Basketball Players, Cheerleaders and band members were also recognized.
In New Business, the board approved strategic goals that were set for the new calendar year submitted by a committee of teachers, board members and district staff.  Supt. Neubaum lead the board through a discussion of the School Maintenance Grant Project through Veregy.  He stated that next year the grant will become a competitive process that could work in the district’s favor.  He said Clay City Schools are in the process of updating the HVAC system around the various buildings.  Since the program appears to favor projects completed in stages, Clay City will likely seek to install the HVAC systems in multiple years and the motion was approved.
Supt Neubaum told the board about a proposal to create a school within a school alternative program.  He explained the district has a small handful of jr. high level students that have fallen behind due to a combination of behavioral and attendance issues.  By creating an alternative school at Clay City, it is hoped that the students can succeed at academic recovery to catch up to what they’ve missed and then move forward and return to regular classes.  This intervention will remove the students from the general student population, and they will have no socialization with other students, except on the way to school and back home.  The students must agree to attend this version of alternative school.  Board members questioned this approach and had other concerns as well.  With encouragement from the supt., members  but did vote unanimously to approve the measure through the end of the current school year.  Supt. Neubaum will update the board about the situation in a month, and the board could agree to continue the program or eliminate it based on what the progress report shows.
The final agenda item was a request to approve the retirement of Kindergarten Teacher Beth Yates, effective at the end of the 2028/29 school year.  The board approved the request unanimously.
Clay City Senior Camden Bruner addressed the board on behalf of the Class of 2026.  He asked the board to approve the Senior Class Trip to Orange Beach, Alabama March 12-15 and discussed their fundraising efforts.  After answering a few questions, the board approved his request without dissent.
And with all business complete, the meeting adjourned.

title: HIGH SPEED CHASE
full_story:
1/16/26
Mannie M. Willis, 26 of Gary, Indiana is behind bars following a high-speed chase Thursday morning in the Geff area.
Wayne County Sheriff Chris Otey reports a deputy spotted a vehicle stopped on the side of the road on US 45 near Geff around 12:35 Thursday morning.  Immediately after the deputy pulled in behind the vehicle, the driver fled.  A lengthy pursuit ensued with speeds of around 100 mph.  The chase continued across rural Wayne County roads and on Route 45.  Sheriff Otey says Willis turned off his head lights multiple times in an attempt to elude police and even slammed on his brakes in an attempt to cause a crash.
Eventually, Willis fled on foot after crashing his car into a ditch.  He was eventually tased by an officer and was taken into custody without further incident.
An inventory of Willis’ vehicle revealed he was in possession of prescription pills and burglary tools.  Sheriff Otey also noted that the license plate matching the vehicle had been removed with a Kentucky plate duct taped to the vehicle.
Willis has been detained in the Wayne County Jail.
Preliminary charges include aggravated fleeing or eluding, obstruction of justice, reckless driving, resisting arrest and multiple traffic citations.
Sheriff Otey says the investigation is ongoing and additional charges are likely.

title: SPICER STATEMENT ON GRANT
full_story:

Flora Mayor Linda Spicer released the following statement about the state approving the city’s OSLAD Grant.
The City of Flora is pleased to announce that it has been selected to receive $344,800 dollars through the Open Space Land Acquisition and Development Grant (OSLAD) used for developing public parks and outdoor recreational spaces in the State of Illinois.  This State grant program is the same program used by the City to construct the popular Pickleball Courts.  The City of Flora was one of a few applications selected in our area.
This project will focus on improving and enhancing the current Rotary Park.  The grant will ensure ADA compliance by making equipment and parking more accessible.  There will be new walking paths and replacement of some outdated equipment.  However, the familiar Rocket Slide will remain a sacred part of the existing park.
The total project will be $689,600 as the grant requires local match funding.  The timeline for start and completion is not defined at this time.  However, the City will move forward with their submitted plans when funds are secured.
The City Council appreciates the many community residents and Flora Rotary for their support at the public hearing held during the past year.  There were also many people who sent letters of support and students who contributed various forms of support.  Mayor Spicer said, “All of these contributions enabled us to secure this valuable grant to expand and improve recreational facilities in our community.
Rotary Park will continue to provide a welcoming space for all of our residents and visitors.”

title: WHITE SQUIRREL COUNT
full_story:
1/16/26
The results of the 47
th
annual Olney squirrel count are in, revealing a decline in the population of both white and grey squirrels.
A total of 105 volunteers participated over three Saturdays in October to conduct the count.  They reported finding 60 white squirrels and 780 grey squirrels.  This represents a decrease of 21 white squirrels and 227 grey squirrels compared to 2024.
Counters noted that more leaves on the trees and increased traffic noise on one Saturday made it difficult to spot the squirrels.
Dr. John Stencel expressed concerns about the future of the Olney white squirrels, suggesting they could be gone by 2034 if no conservation efforts are made.
Suggestions to help preserve the population include providing water and food, as well as setting up houses to offer extra protection from the elements and predators.

title: CARLYLE LAKE RATED
full_story:
1/16/26
Carlyle has been named one of the 12 Best Boating Cities in the United States for the second year in a row.  The list is put together by BoatBooker.
Carlyle Lake is recognized for its calm lake setting, relaxed atmosphere, and the welcoming boating community surrounding Illinois’ largest man-made lake.
BoatBooker notes the wide-open waters are perfect for cruising, sailing, and family-friendly outings.  Visitors can enjoy pontoon rides, speedboat excursions, or fishing trips targeting bass, crappie, and catfish, all supported by experienced local captains and accessible marinas.  Kayaking and paddle boarding are also popular, giving travelers a peaceful way to explore scenic coves and shorelines.
Off the water, BoatBooker finds Carlyle’s trails, picnic areas, campgrounds, and wildlife-viewing spots make it easy to turn a day on the lake into a full outdoor getaway.
The ratings are based on a combination of variety and quality of boating experiences, customer interest and booking trends, accessibility of rivers, lakes, and costal waterways, input from local captains and operators and broader destination appeal and tourism momentum.
Carlyle Lake is the only lake in Illinois to make the list.

title: LINCOLN’S BIRTHDAY AT VANDALIA STATEHOUSE
full_story:

The Vandalia Statehouse State Historic Site will celebrate President Abraham Lincoln’s birthday and America’s 250th anniversary with a free public event from 2 to 4 pm on Saturday, February 7
th
in the House of Representatives chamber where Lincoln once served.
The program will feature Fritz Klein as Lincoln, along with remarks from Vandalia Mayor Doug Knebel and music by the Vandalia Community High School Band.
Klein, a professional actor and speaker, is known for his historically accurate and compelling portrayal of Lincoln.  He bears a striking physical resemblance to the former president and has appeared in documentaries and films for National Geographic, Discovery Channel and the History Channel.
Birthday cake and cookies will be served.  The celebration is presented by the Illinois Department of Natural Resources, the Vandalia Illinois Tourism Commission and the Old Capitol Foundation.
The Vandalia Statehouse State Historic Site is the oldest surviving capitol building in Illinois and served as the state capitol from 1836 to 1839.  The site, at 315 W. Gallatin Street, is open to the public from 9 am to 4 pm Wednesday through Sunday.  For more information, call 618-283-1161.

title: OSLAD GRANT AWARDED
full_story:
1/15/26
Wednesday, Governor JB Pritzker and the Illinois Department of Natural Resources (IDNR) announced $36 million in grant funding was awarded to 67 local park projects throughout Illinois to help communities acquire land and develop recreational opportunities.  The grants were awarded through the Open Space Land Acquisition and Development, or OSLAD, program.
The City of Flora was awarded $344,800 for an accessible park redesign project.
For the fourth year in a row, the governor ensured funding was set aside for economically distressed communities, resulting in 20 underserved communities receiving $11.4 million in OSLAD grants this year.
Established by the Illinois General Assembly in 1986, OSLAD is a cost-sharing program between state and local governments which helps communities fund land acquisition and development for parks and outdoor recreation projects.  It’s become one of the most popular grant programs in Illinois.  Since its establishment, OSLAD has awarded $675 million for park projects throughout Illinois.

title: BOST CASE PROGRESSES
full_story:
1/15/26
US Representative Mike Bost applauded the US Supreme Court’s 7-2 decision Wednesday granting him standing in his lawsuit challenging an Illinois law that allows vote-by-mail ballots received up to 14 days after Election Day to be counted.  Vote-by-mail ballots without postmarks can also currently be tabulated up to 14 days later if they are dated on or before Election Day.
“I’m thankful the US Supreme Court has ruled strongly in our favor and concluded we have standing to challenge Illinois’ unconstitutional law allowing vote-by-mail ballots to be counted two weeks after Election Day,” said Bost.  “This is a critically important step forward in the fight for election integrity and fair elections.  I look forward to continuing to pursue this case as we navigate the next stages of the legal process.  It’s vitally important that we restore the people’s trust in our elections.”
Bost is being represented by Judicial Watch, a conservative foundation that fights for accountability and integrity in law, politics and government.
“This is the most important Supreme Court election law ruling in a generation,” said Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton.  “Too many courts have denied candidates the standing to challenge unlawful election rules such as the outrageous ballots that arrive after Election Day.  American citizens concerned about election integrity should celebrate this Supreme Court victory.  I thank Judicial Watch’s legion of supporters and our election law team that helped achieve this historic result.”
Bost’s election integrity lawsuit was initially filed on May 25, 2022.

title: IFB URGES YEAR-ROUND E15
full_story:
1/15/25
Illinois Farm Bureau signed onto a letter with about 75 other groups urging Congress to pass a legislative solution that allows for the sale of year-round E15 as soon as possible.  The letter was sent to congressional leadership and was signed by groups representing farmers and renewable fuel.
A bipartisan, commonsense bill to permanently allow the sale of year-round, nationwide E15 would boost farm income and lower the price drivers pay at the pump, according to the letter.  The Ag Department projects a more than 17 billion-bushel corn harvest in 2025.  “While this demonstrates the strength and productivity of America’s farmers, it also intensifies pressure on corn prices and farm incomes.  Without new markets, too many bushels will be chasing too few buyers, threatening to deepen the financial strain in rural communities,” the letter states.  “Expanding E15 access is one of the most immediate and practical ways to address this imbalance.”
A recent study found nationwide, year-round E15 sales would add up to $25.8 billion to US Gross Domestic Product, generate up to $10.3 billion in household income and support more than 128,000 new full-time jobs across the economy, the letter states.  For consumers, E15 typically sells for 10 to 30 cents less per gallon than standard gasoline, and more than 95% of vehicles on the road are approved to use the fuel.  In recent years, E15 availability during the summer driving season has depended on temporary emergency waivers.
“Year-to-year uncertainty discourages investment in fuel infrastructure, confuses consumers and undermines confidence among retailers and refiners,” according to the letter.  “With record corn and sorghum crops filling bins across America, farmers cannot afford another season of uncertainty and negative margins.  Markets need consistency and predictability, which requires permanent legislative action by Congress.”
The Illinois Corn Growers Association and Illinois Renewable Fuels Association also signed the letter.

title: GIRL SCOUT COOKIES
full_story:
1/13/26
It’s officially Girl Scout Cookie season in Southern Illinois.  Girl Scouts throughout the area will hold cookie booths, visit customers door-to-door, and sell to friends and family online as they explore more possibilities through the largest girl-led entrepreneurial program in the world.
During this highly anticipated time of the year, girls acquire five important life skills, goal setting, decision making, money management, people skills, and business ethics.  All proceeds from cookie sales stay local to power Girl Scout adventures year-round.  Every box of cookies sold provides invaluable experiences for Girl Scouts such as service projects, troop travel, STEM programs, and summer camp.
Loretta Graham, Chief Executive Officer for Girl Scouts of Southern Illinois said, “When people support the Girl Scout Cookie Program, they aren’t just purchasing cookies.  They are fueling experiences and empowering girls to explore new adventures – all while girls gain skills that last a lifetime.  The cookies that customers receive in return are a ‘thank you’ for building girls of courage, confidence, and character, who make the world a better place.”
Exploremores, a rocky road ice cream–inspired sandwich cookie, will join the legendary lineup for the 2026 Girl Scout Cookie season.  Filled with delicious flavors of chocolate, marshmallow, and toasted almond–flavored crème, Exploremores reflect the spirit of exploration at the heart of every Girl Scout.  In addition to the exciting new cookie, the 2026 cookie lineup will include fan favorites such as Thin Mints, Samoas, Tagalongs, and more.
Booths are starting to pop up throughout the region this week.  To find a booth near you or to order cookies online, visit gsofsi.org/findcookies.  While picking up some cookies for yourself, you can also purchase a box or two to donate to the Bake It Forward program.  All cookies purchased through Bake It Forward will be donated to H.E.R.O.E.S. Care – an organization supporting military personnel and their families.  The Girl Scout Cookie Program runs through March 15
th
in Southern Illinois.
Girl Scouts of Southern Illinois serves over 6,300 girls and engages nearly 3,600 adults in 40 counties in Southern Illinois.  Call 800-345-6858 or email
.  Girl Scouts of Southern Illinois is a not-for-profit organization supported by United Ways, businesses, and individual donors throughout the region.

title: DEADLINE EXTENDED
full_story:
1/13/26
Get Covered Illinois announced Monday that it is giving residents an additional 16 days to enroll in health insurance through the state’s official marketplace.  Customers now have until January 31
st
to apply for and enroll in coverage.
“We are seeing record numbers of customers finding more affordable coverage by taking the time to shop for and compare plans” said Morgan Winters, Director of Get Covered Illinois.  “As a state-based marketplace, not only do we now have the authority to offer this special enrollment extension, but we also have more resources to support our customers in finding affordable health coverage options.”
Illinois invested nearly $7 million dollars into navigator grants that provide enrollment support to residents and has built a strong certified broker network.  Brokers are critical enrollment partners who both help customers navigate the application and enrollment process and provide individual plan recommendations.  These services are free to Illinois residents.
“There are more than 140 navigators and 9,000 brokers located around the state who stand ready to help our customers apply for and enroll in quality health coverage,” said Ezra Watland, Chief Operating Officer at Get Covered Illinois.  “I recommend anyone needing health coverage or who hasn’t taken the time to compare their options, use this additional time to reach out to a broker or navigator.”
Illinois residents can connect with navigators and brokers by using the Get Covered Illinois online directory.
The deadline for enrolling in coverage starting February 1
st
, is January 31
st
.  Visit GetCoveredIllinois.gov to apply and enroll or call our Customer Assistance Center at 1-866-311-1119 (TTY: 711).  The Customer Assistance Center is offering extended hours through January 31
st
.
Get Covered Illinois is the state’s official health insurance marketplace and a division of the Illinois Department of Insurance.  We help residents shop, compare, and enroll in quality, affordable health coverage under the Affordable Care Act.  Free, one-on-one enrollment help is available statewide from trained navigators and licensed brokers, in person, by phone, and online, with support in multiple languages.

title: PRELIMINARY HEARING FINALLY HELD
full_story:
1/13/26
The long-delayed preliminary hearing for former Wabash County Sheriff’s Deputy Chase Cheadle was held on Thursday, where a judge found probable cause in the case.  Cheadle entered a plea of not guilty to the remaining charges.  A pretrial hearing has been scheduled for February 19
th
.
Cheadle’s preliminary hearing had been postponed multiple times, with delays dating back to November of 2024.
The former sheriff’s department canine handler was originally charged with eight counts, including four counts of official misconduct, one count of theft, one count of cruelty to animals, and two counts of animal owner duties violations.  Five of those charges were felonies.
However, in June, Special Prosecutor Brian Towne requested dismissal of two felony counts, the theft charge and one count of official misconduct, which were granted by the court.
According to investigators, the 30-year-old Cheadle found his K-9 partner, Kiki, unresponsive in July of 2024.  He was later arrested following the investigation and resigned from the Wabash County Sheriff’s Department one month later.

title: THEIS RETIRES
full_story:
1/13/26
Illinois Supreme Court Justice Mary Jane Theis announced her retirement from the Illinois Supreme Court effective January 29
th
. Justice Theis has served on the Supreme Court since 2010 and retires as one of the most prolific judges in Illinois history, having served in all levels of the judiciary in 40-plus years on the bench.  She served as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court from 2022 to 2025.
The Supreme Court has constitutional authority to fill interim judicial vacancies and has appointed First District Appellate Court Justice Sanjay T. Tailor to fill Justice Theis’ seat.
Justice Tailor, whose term is effective January 30
th
, through December 4
th
, 2028, will be the first Asian American to serve on the Illinois Supreme Court.
Justice Sanjay Tailor has been a judge for 23 years, sitting on the trial and appellate courts.  His appointment makes him the first Asian American to serve as a justice of the Illinois Supreme Court.  He was first appointed to the bench as an Associate Judge in 2003 and won election as Circuit Judge in 2022.  He served in five different divisions of the Circuit Court including as Presiding Judge of the County Division.  He also served in the Chancery, Law, Domestic Relations and Municipal Divisions.  For the last three years he has served by assignment as a First District Appellate Court justice, including as Presiding Justice of his division.
Before joining the bench, Justice Tailor served as an Assistant State’s Attorney in the Cook County State’s Attorney’s Office.  He also practiced law as a senior attorney at the First National Bank of Chicago, and associate at Chapman and Cutler LLP.

title: WABASH COMMUNICATIONS SCHOLARSHIP

Wabash Communications awards more than $20,000 in scholarships annually to graduating high school seniors across the service area.
To qualify for the Wabash Communications scholarships your parent or legal guardian must be a member/customer of Wabash Communications or Wabash Communications Co-op, you plan to continue your education after high school at University or College, Junior college, Trade school, or Certification program.  Any field of study qualifies, there is no GPA minimum, and there are no extracurricular requirements.
Education is expensive.  These scholarships are meant to help offset those costs so students can stay focused on what’s next, whether that’s college, technical training, or a certification program.  If you’re continuing your education, you’re eligible to apply.
The application process is straightforward, complete the application and required information at
.  Submit your application by March 6
th
there is no application fee.
If you’re a graduating senior and meet the eligibility requirements, don’t wait.  This is an opportunity to receive financial support from a local cooperative that’s invested in your future.

title: COUNTY BOARD MEETING
full_story:
1/14/25 Beth Fancher
The Clay County Board met in regular session last night.
Ted Whitehead, Representative for Snedeker Risk Management presented Joe Goodman, Clay County Board Chairman with a dividend check for $13,440.  Snedeker Risk Management  runs the HOPE Trust and members own the trust, which provides health benefits to county, school district, city, village and other local government employees throughout the State of Illinois.  Since commencing 15 years ago, there are currently 30 public entities and schools participating in the program.
County Engineer Darin Koelm announced they will be posting seasonal weight limits from January 15
th
to April 15
th
.  “There are four ways to find weight limits,” Koelm said.  “You can call the office 24 /7 and the up-to-date weight limits are listed, as well as looking on the website, also WNOI lists the weight limits and the sheriff’s office has the latest limits.  We will do whatever we can to help and are just asking county residents to help us maintain the county roads.”
Koelm received approval for the engineer’s report, approval for the local public agency amendment of the joint funding agreement and apprised the board the department has received $750,000 from an IDOT grant.  He said they would use the money for the Hickory Hill and Butternut Road project.
State’s Attorney Phillip Givens received approval for an interim intergovernmental agreement for the Village of Louisville to receive animal control services through Clay County.
Heather Greenwood, team leader with Partners for Progress Deflection Initiative provided the board with information concerning the multiple counties program with community-based resources to assist individuals struggling with substance use, mental health challenges or housing insecurities.  Greenwood said there will be two deflective specialists assigned to Clay County to help keep people out of the justice system or from returning.
Law enforcement will make referrals, and the specialists will keep track of the individuals.  “We will be launching an event in Flora at the Church of the Nazarene on March 4
th
,” Greenwood explained.  “More information will be announced on the upcoming event.”
The board passed an intergovernmental agreement and passed an ordinance for public transportation presented by Central Illinois Public Transit.
Clay County Hospital CEO and President Bob Sellers said there was a meeting for bid contractors.  The bids will be announced for the grant project for building a new Health Department at the February Hospital Board and then to the County Board meeting.  Sellers received approval for the Hospital Report, approval to have Lindy Kohn’s name added to the Bank ACH authorizations and approval to purchase hospital waiting room furniture and two infusion recliners for $72,895.  He also announced the hospital has signed a contract with Chiropractor Brittany Hoselton.  She will be working in the Louisville Clinic and said he felt this would add a new holistic realm of the medical needs the hospital can offer.
Sheriff Andy Myers obtained authorization for the Sheriff’s Office report for December and secured approval for a Major Case Squad Intergovernmental Agreement.  “The squad will be made up of officers from I-70 south,” Sheriff Myers said.  “With Lt. Abner’s experience I think he will fit the needs.  There will be no money exchange since we will be working together.”
Board member Terry Hronec with the board executive finance committee, received approval for the following purchases paid out of the Capital Expenditure Account: a track hoe for the Highway Department; a server for the courthouse, $18,719.29; computers for the County Clerk’s Office, $7,988 and scuba gear for ESDA, $13,895.89.
A resolution was passed ensuring county office holders reimburse the county for associated benefits match payroll costs on employee stipend/bonuses.
Board member Barbara McGrew was appointed as a member of the Southern Illinois Economic Development Authority (SIEDA) board.  She will be replacing board member Jeremy Kohn who asked to be replaced because of meeting times.
The transfer of the proceeds for the sale of 935 Bryant Street, in Louisville to Clay County Hospital, $94,887 was approved for bookkeeping purposes.  A six-month extension for Kemper CPA to complete the Circuit Clerk’s audit was approved.
Board member Barb McGrew read the results of the December Claims Committee meeting.  There was $3,315,180.84 paid claims and $352,636.85 unpaid claims from the Hospital; $802,063.40 paid claims and $75.00 unpaid claims from County Highway; $780,479.54 paid claims and $2,819.77 unpaid claims from the Health Department; $258,509.31 paid claims from Clay County; $2,801.50 paid claims from 911; $108,529.16 paid claims from the Public Safety Tax and $4,616.45 paid claims from Animal Control.
The December Sheriff’s Department activity report included issuing 21 traffic citations, 25 criminal arrests served 26 various civil papers, conducted 30 criminal investigations and 17 accident investigations.  There were 19 people processed through the jail.  The Sheriff’s Office received $653.60 which included: $528 civil process; $6 E-citations; $89.60 IDOC transport fees and $30 report fees.

title: CLIP AND TIP STRAYS (C.A.T.S.)
full_story:
1/14/26
Twenty Clay County cats were sterilized on Tuesday, January 13
th
at a Spay & Neuter Clinic Day in Flora run by the nonprofit Clip and Tip Strays (C.A.T.S.).
Licensed traveling veterinarian Dr. Meghann Jerden conducted the surgeries at the Wags and Wash Salon at 421 West North Avenue in Flora.  Five C.A.T.S. volunteers from Louisville and Flora assisted.
Surgeries were done at affordable rates: $80 for a spay and $50 for a neuter and included rabies vaccination.  The 10 female and 10 male cats were outside community cats, barn cats, and inside owned cats.  Surgeries were funded by cat owners and caretakers.
Cat Osterholtz, founder/chairperson of C.A.T.S., and owner of Wags and Wash Salon, said: “This is our second large Spay & Neuter Clinic Day with Dr. Jerden coming to Flora.  Our first Clinic Day in November sterilized 38 cats. Last month, our volunteers transported 10 cats to her location for surgeries.  Within a short span, our program has helped 68 cats in Clay County get on the road to healthier, longer lives.  We plan to conduct a sterilization clinic once a month to reduce the cat overpopulation problem in our county.”
Spaying/neutering not only stops the breeding cycle, it also delivers numerous behavioral and health benefits for both male and female cats.
Clip and Tip Strays (C.A.T.S.) is a new, volunteer-driven nonprofit based in Flora.  The group aims to raise funds through fundraisers and donations and conduct Trap-Neuter-Release (TNR) as a cost-effective, humane way to control the feral and stray feline population in Clay County.  C.A.T.S. also offers traps and carriers to cat owners and caretakers for trapping and transport.
Follow C.A.T.S. on its Facebook page for upcoming Clinic Day updates or call/text 618-662-3837, or contact them by mail at PO Box 23, Flora, IL 62839.

title: XENIA VILLAGE BOARD MEETING
full_story:
1-13-2026Timothy Russell
The Xenia Village Board met in regular session last night.
All trustees were in attendance including the village attorney who attended via speaker phone.
The First item of business on the agenda was the appointment of Logan Dye to the Gateway water and sewer board of Trustees.  Followed by the approval of minutes from December’s meeting, and approval of the treasure’s report, and bills.
It was reported that water loss of 8% or 69,332 gallons for November thru December and 13% or 92,448 gallons for December thru January.  In old business, the board of trustees discussed recent construction work which had taken place on one property that had been purchased and remained vacant for some time.  Updates were provided on the Slagley property which trustees hoped might become the location of a Dollar General in the village.  However, the site was rejected due to its small size.
The Knapp gas station located in Xenia also closed unexpectedly last month after a visit from the Department of Revenue and is not expected to re-open.
The status of the IMRF state retirement fund for the village remains uncertain after months with no updates.  The Villages attorney plans to reach out to state representatives regarding the matter.
In police Business Officer Jerry Burkett told trustees that repairs had been made to police cruisers including a new battery in the Explorer and a new grill on the Impala.
Trustees discussed options for repair and or replacement of the heating and air conditioning in the cafeteria and gathering options for the placement of a notice of bid for the repairs.  No action was taken on the matter after a question of numerous repairs to the gym were raised, and it could be determined which repair were a higher priority as well as where the money for repairs would come from.  Trustees discussed bringing in city engineer Mike Bridges to make assessments before any decision is made.
The reestablishing of committees to enforce village ordinances was also discussed before being tabled, citing the need for more information on how the committees’ function and clearer outlines of committee duties and responsibilities.  The Villages police breakfast was set for February 6
th
from 6 to 10 am.  Options of biscuits and gravy, eggs and sausage and possibly cinnamon rolls will be available to those who attend.

title: KINMUNDY FIRE
full_story:
1/14/26
One person was burned at about 4:30 on Monday afternoon when a fire destroyed a barn in rural Kinmundy.
Kinmundy-Alma Fire Chief Kevin Day says Trevor Robins was using a cooker inside a barn on Meachum Road.  Robins says he was using a cooker when he heard a propane tank beginning to pop off.  He told everyone to get out, but before he was able to exit a flash fire occurred.  Robins received first and second degree burns to his face and arms and was transported to Salem Township Hospital.
When firemen arrived on the scene, Chief Day says the fire had fully engulfed the 30 by 60 foot pole barn.  The barn along with a car, boat, and three propane tanks were destroyed.  Firemen were on scene for about 2 hours.

title: EFFINGHAM TEACHER ARRESTED
full_story:
1/14/26
A teacher was arrested by Effingham Police on Friday after they said he sent “inappropriate electronic messages” to a student.
In a news release Monday afternoon, Effingham Police officials said they took a report on Friday alleging this communication between a student and 32-year-old Dakota M. Czerwonka Montrose.  Czerwonka was described as the founder of Crossroads Montessori School in Effingham, where he also taught.
The Effingham County State’s Attorney’s Office charged Czerwonka with one count of grooming and one count of sexual exploitation of a child.  They are both Class 4 felonies punishable by one to three years in prison and mandatory sex offender registration if convicted.
The State’s Attorney’s Office has filed petition to detain Czerwonka throughout the pretrial phase of his case.  Grooming is a detainable offense under the SAFE-T Act, and the Effingham Police Department supports detention due to Czerwonka’s occupation and the victim’s status as a student and minor.
Czerwonka made his first court appearance on Monday.

title: LAKER ACADEMIC INVITATIONAL
full_story:

On Friday, February 6
th
, Lake Land College will host local high school students for the first-ever Laker Academic Invitational, a competitive event designed to challenge and recognize academic excellence.
During the event, more than 300 students across 17 local high schools will compete in a series of multiple-choice exams, demonstrating their knowledge in biology, chemistry, computer science, software applications, English, mathematics and physics.  Through these experiences, the event fosters curiosity and confidence as students challenge themselves in a supportive environment and explore future college and career pathways.
The Laker Academic Invitational was designed to provide an engaging academic challenge for high school students following the discontinuation of the traditional ACES competition, which was previously held every year at Lake Land College.

title: CORN YIELDS
full_story:
1/14/26
USDA estimates American corn farmers produced more than 17 billion bushels of corn in 2025.
The record estimate, higher than the average trade guess, was boosted by a significant increase in harvested acres.  Since the June acreage report, the agency bumped its harvested area estimate by 4.5 million acres to 91.25 million – the highest since 1933.  The corn yield estimate was also higher at a record 186.5 bushels per acre, up from 179.3 in 2024.
USDA pegged Illinois corn production from last season at 2.35 billion bushels with an average yield of 214 bushels per acre, down 3.2% from its November estimate.
The higher production number boosted ending stocks, now seen at 2.22 billion bushels nationwide.  According to the quarterly stocks report released the same day, U.S. quarterly corn stocks on December 1
st
were 13.82 billion bushels, up from 12 billion the year prior.
U.S. soybean production came in at 4.26 billion bushels, with harvested area of 80.4 million acres and a record average yield of 53 bushels per acre, all slightly above trade expectations.  Yield was higher than 2024/25 but production was lower due to fewer harvested acres.  For Illinois, soybean yield was down 3.8% from November at 62.5 bushels per acre.
Soybean stocks estimates are 350 million bushels, up from 290 million in December.  Quarterly stocks on December 1
st
were at 3.29 billion, up from 3.1 billion a year ago.
USDA also increased Brazilian soybean production by 3 million metric tons as the country’s harvest begins.
While the January estimates are considered USDA’s final revisions to 2025 corn and soybean production, Camp said the agency could still make adjustments.  But it likely would not be until the September report.
For winter wheat, the agency estimates U.S. farmers planted 32.99 million acres in 2025, slightly above trade expectations but below the year prior (33.15 million).  Wheat ending stocks were pegged at 926 million bushels, up from 901 million in December due to lower use.  Quarterly stocks for wheat came in at 1.68 billion bushels.

title: A part that broke on a UPS plane that crashed in Kentucky failed 4 times on other planes years ago
full_story:
AP
A part that broke on a UPS plane that crashed in Kentucky failed 4 times on other planes years ago
The National Transportation Safety Board says Boeing warned plane owners in 2011 about a flaw in the part that failed and contributed to the engine flying off a UPS plane before it crashed and killed 15 in November but at that point the planemaker didn’t believe it threatened safety
By JOSH FUNK - AP Transportation Writer
Jan 14, 2026
Jan 14, 2026
Updated
1 hr ago
Copy article link
Boeing warned plane owners in 2011 about a broken part that contributed to a UPS plane crash that killed 15 last year but at that point the planemaker didn't believe it threatened safety, the National Transportation Safety Board said Wednesday.
The
in November 2025 shortly after taking off in Louisville, when the
as the plane rolled down the runway.
The NTSB said Wednesday that Boeing had documented in 2011 there were four previous failures of a part that helps secure the MD-11's engines to the wings on three different planes, but at that point the planemaker "determined it would not result in a safety of flight condition."
NTSB didn't say whether there had been additional documented failures of the spherical bearing race since 2011. Investigators found that part broken into two pieces after the UPS crash, and the lugs that held that part were cracked.
Photos released by the NTSB of the Nov. 4 crash show flames erupting as the rear of the engine starting to detach before it flew up and over the wing. Then the wing was engulfed by fire as the burning engine flew above it.
on the plane that was headed for Hawaii were killed along with
on the ground near Louisville's Muhammad Ali International Airport.
The factual report released Wednesday doesn’t state what caused the engine to fly off. That conclusion won't come until the NTSB's final report, which usually doesn't come until more than a year after a crash.
Boeing, UPS and the Federal Aviation Administration are limited on what they can say while the NTSB investigation is ongoing.
UPS spokesperson Jim Mayer reiterated that the company was devastated by the crash. “We remain profoundly saddened by the Flight 2976 accident. Our thoughts continue to be with the families and Louisville community who are grieving, and we remain focused on the recovery effort,” Mayer said.
The NTSB previously said investigators
in some of the parts that held the engine to the wing. Those cracks hadn't been caught in regular maintenance done on the plane, which raised questions about the adequacy of the maintenance schedule. The last time those key engine mount parts were examined closely was in October 2021, and the plane wasn't due for another detailed inspection for roughly 7,000 more takeoffs and landings.
The 34-year-old MD-11 plane only got 30 feet (9.1 meters) off the ground before crashing into several industrial buildings just past the runway and generating a massive fireball that could be
. Dramatic videos of the crash showed the plane on fire as it plowed into buildings and released a massive plume of smoke.
Airlines quit flying this type of plane commercially years ago because it isn't as efficient as newer models, but they had continued to fly for cargo carriers like UPS and FedEx and a few of these planes were also modified for use in firefighting. All the MD-11s that had been in use and 10 related DC-10s have been
.
It's not clear when the cracks started to develop in the engine mounting pylon parts, but this crash is reminiscent of a 1979 crash in Chicago when the left engine flew off an American Airlines DC-10 during takeoff, killing 273 people. The DC-10 was the predecessor of the MD-11.
That previous crash led to the worldwide grounding of 274 DC-10s. The airline workhorse was allowed to return to the skies because the NTSB determined that maintenance workers damaged the plane that crashed while improperly using a forklift to reattach the engine. That meant the crash wasn’t caused by a fatal design flaw even though there had already been a number of accidents involving DC-10s.
